Counter-Strike is one of the biggest names in the PC gaming community, and for good reason: it revolutionized multiplayer FPS games. After the original CS hit shelves, along with 1.6 and Source, Counter-Strike: Global Offensive has set the bar even higher, and jumped over it tenfold.

Sticking close to it's roots, Global Offensive employs it's famous bomb defusal and hostage mission game modes (available in both "casual" and ranked 5v5 "competetive" types), along with integrating some other fun modes, such as arms race and deathmatch. Bomb and hostage scenarios are lead by a buying system, encouraging successful kills and objectives (like planting the bomb) to aid in buying gear in the next round. Players are required to use teamwork and tactics in order to come out on top against the enemy team, and winning a game gives a sense of satisfaction unlike any other first-person shooter game I've ever experienced.

If you are expecting this game to be anything like Call of Duty or Battlefield, you will be sorely disappointed. Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is an excellent addition to the CS saga, and I strongly recommend picking it up and giving it a try.

Pros:

Yet another Counter-Strike game which delivers in every aspect of competitive and fun gameplay. The transition between one CS game to this one may be difficult for some because it does differ. But, If you're a CS Veteran and fan like me, you owe it to yourself to buy this game.

If you're familiar with the CS games, then you probably already know that CS is a blast to play with friends. CS games take skill and practice, and therefor it's really fun and exciting to improve your skill and display it online in the competitve scene. There is no other FPS that matches the satisfaction of managing to pull off a 1v5 clutch, or get an ace in the compititive game mode. And this is where the game shines, and will keep me coming back for more.

Like recent CS games, this is also a FPS game with a long lifespan and great replayability. Global Offensive gives us a big graphical improvement compared to the older CS games and adds a few new features into the mix. Popular custom community game modes from the recent CS games, like Gun Game and Deathmatch, have been implemented popular in CS:GO as official game modes which I think is a great addition. They've added a few new weapons and gadgets, a bunch of different and interesting tweaks on the original CS maps and they've also added an official Competitive game mode too. Here you get assigned a rank based on your skill and performances. Competitive mode is where this game truly stands out from other CS games, but, here, is where most of the cons of the game lay.

Cons:

Firstly, Competitve and other official game mode servers are strictly locked to 64 tick servers. This will be something that many will find very hard to get used to, and personally, I think it's down right crap. Since every other CS game has 128 tick servers, I don't understand valves dicision here. Do they want to earn more money? Do they care? Either way this is a problem that Valve has to address, especially for all the competitive players who really notice the difference.

Secondly, the VAC system. Now this my freinds, is the real issue with this game. And in the perfect world this wouldn't have to be an issue, but as we know, there's always that kid who doesn't give a shit and decides to turn on some of his hacks/cheats, like the infamous wall hack, aim bot or trigger bot. 

Now, one should not have to want to play the game but at the same time not want to becuase there's a 50 50 procent chance to end up against a hacker in competitive matchmaking. The VAC system relies on player reports and people reviewing other peoples gameplay. Sounds good right? Well, no, the system bans in waves instead of on the spot, some people can go weeks with hacks without getting banned.


All in all, this is a great game, and I would possibly give it a higher rating if they manage to address some of these issues. But I definately would recommend this game to newcomers out there and the veterans.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is the pinnacle in online competitive gaming.

CS:GO is a 5-on-5 competitive first-person shooter with multiple official and many community-made gamemodes, the most commonly played one being DE, also known as the Bomb Defusal mode. This is the competitive gamemode of CS:GO, and also where the game really shines. We will be focusing on the Bomb Defusal mode in this review.

In CS:GO, the rules are simple. Terrorists have to either plant a bomb in one of the two sites, or take out the whole Counter-Terrorist team to win the round, while the Counter-Terrorists have to either defuse the bomb, or take out the Terrorist team.

The tight angles and narrow, near-claustrophobic indoor areas make the game very intense and fast-paced, while some maps still offer the wide, big areas for snipers to take advantage of. The atmosphere of the maps are stunning as always expected from Valve games. While the overall graphical quality is not nearly as good as the most recent shooters of our time, it still stands out to this day mostly due to it's amazing map themes and detailed modelwork.

This game is not for the lone wolf FPS gamer, teamwork is heavily required throughout a match from simple boosts to extremely-planned bombsite retakes. You will find yourself talking to your teammates a lot and giving them info on where the enemies are. Of course, this doesn't mean individual skill isn't nearly as important as teamplay. It's not as easy as it is to shoot the enemy than to see them.

The weapons control similar to the classic pattern scheme every Counter-Strike game has had since the first game. All weapons have recoil that consists of a simple pattern that goes upwards until a certain point, and the added factor of movement and being shot really makes this game's weapons an easy to use, difficult to master beast. Almost every weapon is equally balanced, and it is quite possible to win a fight against a sniper rifle with an M4A4 on a long range.
While the weapons on CS:GO do not follow realistic examples of recoil and damage, the fire rate is close to the real counterparts of the weapons.

The health system is the classic 100HP from most Source games, but with the added factor of armor. While wearing a Kevlar Vest significantly lowers damage on the upper body, the higher-price Kevlar + Helmet saves you from a headshot or two whilist in combat against an enemy player.

The game uses a money-based economy as a way to obtain weapons and gear. Every team gains money upon killing a player, winning a round, losing a round, planting the bomb etc.
The players cannot share money between eachother, thus making the communication aspect shine once more with players dropping eachother weapons to get an equal footing with the enemy's economy. The Terrorists use stronger but more unstable weapons that require tap-firing and good aim, while the Counter-Terrorists side has more spray-based weapons with low damage but very stable spray patterns that make it easier to rain hell on an oncoming enemy as they approach.

The game is extremely fun when played with a full team or with friends who know eachother well. However, the same fun factor isn't really there when playing the game on Competitive Matchmaking. The players are way more serious here as expected from a Competitive shooter, but some players can be really toxic, engage in verbal abuse, or be very unhelpful to the team in general with insults shooting off all over the place, creating unneccesary inner war between team members. This is a huge drawback for what the game offers, as teamwork is a big part of the game, and when you miss out on it, chaos ensues.

For the more casual players seeking alone fun out of this game, there are gamemodes such as Deathmatch, Surf, Aim and Bunnyhop that you can find in the Community Server Browser hosted by other players to enjoy. However, since the last few updates, Valve seems to be attempting to depracate this feature and make everyone focus on the official gamemodes as much as they can.

The SDK for the game is not very good, and very outdated. We're looking forward to what Source 2 will bring as a way of editing maps and content stored in the game. However, the much popular in-game currency of the game, skins, have much more settings to fiddle around with.

Skins are a huge addition to the game included with the Arms Deal update a few years back. They range from cheap to expensive, depending on quality. The worst being Battle-Scarred, and the best being Factory New. The conditions of the weapons make them differ heavily in price and aesthethics. Some prefer Battle-Scarred, while some prefer Factory New.
The Price of these weapons range from a low low price of 3 cents, going up to a whopping 5 thousand US dollars, depending on what you're looking for. Knives are especially the more rare and expensive skins within the game. Skins are obtained through either the Community Market or by opening Cases. Cases are usually very cheap but require a key you pay for to open. Upon opening a Case you have a chance of dropping a very expensive weapon or a knife, to a very cheap, nearly useless weapon several times cheaper than the key itself. However these skins are only cosmetic and do not change the stats of a weapon, so you do not need them to gain an advantage over another player.

I rate this game a Flaming Russian Vocabulary/10. There are definitely flaws in the community, but the gameplay is super, and the competitive scene is filled with new teams. :D

Counter Strike: Global Offensive, a victim of its popularity. Just like its map, Dust 2.

What can I say? It's filled with hackers, smurfs, griefers, annoying kids, and salty players. Valve sees the game as a business and runs it like one. They don't tend to listen (despite fanboys saying otherwise) to the players and put out cosmetics when they can be improving the state of the game. Counter Strike: Global Offensive definitely has the potential to be one of the greatest games out there, with very high replayability. However, its community is what draws the game back.

Counter Strike contains tons of fan-made content which ranges from maps to weapon-cosmetics. Almost everything in Counter Strike: Global Offensive has been built off of its players. Now, its infested with a plethora of toxicity. Yes, you may occasionally find a few gems in the playerbase, but it's getting harder each day.

In reality, it's all about perspective. You can see this game as a tool to create a career (esports) out of, and to compete with other teams with programs such as FaceIt or CEVO. You can also see it as a fun and casual game you play with your mates, laughing at the hackers/salty kids/whatever. Maybe even join in with the fun and be a hacker or griefer yourself! 

Counter Strike: Global Offensive is a great game with tons of content both within the game and in the workshop. Really fun, especially with friends, and can be a way of casually competing. What I stress about though is Valve's business practices and the fanbase. But who am I to see how Valve should operate? After all, they've made millions off of this game and their gaming platform, Steam, has risen  to the TOP of the charts. 

TL;DR - Great game with tons of content. High replayability value and much funner with friends. Toxic community and greedy Valve is ruining it slowly, though. It will be the funnest game you've played, but you'll still hate it.

"If you could see it, then you'd understand." That glistening anti-koan punctuates the chorus of Coldplay's skyscraping 2005 single "Speed of Sound", and the lyric's profound meaninglessness has doubled as a mission statement for the mega-band's career thus far. They've established a reputation as mainstream rock's koi pond architects, designing music that's deceptively shallow but, if caught at the right moment, shimmeringly beautiful, to the point that you could focus on it for hours.

Impossibly indulgent on a sonic level while retaining the intellectual depth of a cell phone commercial, Coldplay's catalog is largely experiential—a reflecting pool for the hopes, dreams, and heartaches that listeners wish to apply to the music. This pliability has meant that Coldplay can come off as impersonal, a gaseous giant of anonymity in rock music's solar system; nearly 10 years ago, the stultifyingly dense third album X&Y threatened to swallow the band completely, as Coldplay refined the post-post-punk affectations of 2002's A Rush of Blood to the Head until they were left with an immobile monolith.

On the verge of overreaching, Coldplay doubled down with 2008's Viva La Vida or Death and All His Friends, a world-beating document of giddy experimentation and costume-rock bathos that stands as their most thrilling, impressionistic work. Mylo Xyloto followed three years later, which took its predecessor's widescreen template and enlarged it to IMAX-size, indulging in rave-y piano stabs and night-flight flourishes with the color-filled exuberance of a child that can't stop eating crayons.

Mylo Xyloto was further proof that Coldplay are at their best when they embrace their corniest impulses; their sixth album, Ghost Stories, finds them taking a sharp left turn. Preceded by the non-single "Midnight", a watery electro-folk Bon Iver facsimile accompanied with a video reminiscent of an iTunes visualizer, nearly everything about the arrival of Ghost Stories has seemed small: the nine-song tracklist, the spartan, deep-blue angel's-wings cover, the disappointing lack of costumes. The absence of grandiosity signaled to eager fans and sneering bystanders alike that, this time around, something might be a little off.

That something can be traced to Martin's marriage to actress and $600-hand-cream guru Gwyneth Paltrow, which quietly imploded in March of this year. More a separation than an outright divorce, recent court documents revealed that the couple are still living together, and in a 2008 SPIN profile, the only subject that the otherwise affable Martin bristled against discussing was his personal life with Paltrow. As long as the world's known him, Chris Martin has also proved impossible to truly know, so whether his recent familial troubles would seep into his band's latest was anyone's guess.

And yet, Ghost Stories is unmistakably Coldplay's "breakup album," a subdued work that finds Martin and his band crisply moping through mid-tempo soundscapes and fuzzy electronic touches that have the visceral impact of a down comforter tumbling down a flight of stairs. Featuring production from longtime collaborators Daniel Green and Rik Simpson, along with behind-the-boards pro Paul Epworth, drone-techno auteur Jon Hopkins, and Kanye West collaborator Mike Dean, the record is serene and weightless to a fault. Coldplay abandon the musical tourism and extroverted strides of their last few albums and find themselves adrift.

The closest the record comes to a bona fide anthem is the moderately enjoyable "A Sky Full of Stars", a rocket-fueled single on the level of "Clocks" and "Speed of Sound" tainted by Swedish dance producer AVICII's cheap-sounding drum presets and boilerplate synth motifs. "I don't care/ If you tear me apart," Martin wails at the peak of the song's endless chorus, a passionate exclamation that doubles one of the most nakedly personal admissions he's made on record.

Ghost Stories certainly sounds like the product of someone working out their private pain in public; unfortunately, the results are less Blood on the Tracks and more "Can I Borrow a Feeling?". Coldplay's catalog has plenty of examples where Martin's words have failed him, but his diaristic reflections on Ghost Stories are abnormally painful. "Tell me you love me/ If you don't, then lie," he coos on the Spandau Ballet-gone-Disney ballad "True Love"; during the plodding "Another's Arms", he ruminates on lost domestic bliss watching TV with a loved one, "Your body on my body." If the expression of carnal closeness-via-TiVo makes you cringe, imagine how he feels.

"Ink" is the album's most indefensible moment, musically and lyrically, and the song handily snatches the title of Worst Coldplay Song from X&Y's impossibly leaden, fuckin'-magnets stinker "What If". "Got a tattoo/ And the pain's alright," Martin cries while running through a series of love-as-permanence metaphors, over rippling guitar and burbling atmospherics ripped from Phil Collins' Tarzan soundtrack. The last time Coldplay indulged in "rainforest rock," it was Viva La Vida's transcendent, gorgeous "Strawberry Swing", which featured Martin exclaiming beatifically, "It's such a perfect day"; on "Ink", he moves from vine to vine until swinging in solitude at the track's end, exclaiming with a sigh, "All I know is that I love you so/ So much that it hurts."

Fittingly, "Ink" is one of the few tracks on Ghost Stories that leaves a mark, and that's partially due to Martin's lovely-as-ever vocals; when not chronicling his own pain, he occasionally breaks into appealing birdsong, a wordless pitter-patter that marks the chorus of the record's pleasant-enough lead single, "Magic". Otherwise, Ghost Stories is a collection of unmemorable songs from a band that's made enough memories to last a lifetime. Everything sounds pristine—this is a Coldplay album, and instrumentally the band is as exacting as ever—but by the dreary piano-led closer "O", you're left with a series of songs that are fragile, plain, and forgettable.

Conventional wisdom says X&Y is Coldplay's worst album, but amidst that record's shiftless bloat, there were real-deal highlights that hit with blunt impact and have since stood the test of time. Ghost Stories contains no such moments, and thus threatens to rob X&Y of its dubious title. Its intimate nature shares the most kinship with Coldplay's first album, 2000's peerless Parachutes. Twelve years later, that album sounds like the work of a different band, and that's because it is; Coldplay have become one of the biggest acts in the world since their comparatively modest debut, and as a result Ghost Stories' attempts to return to close-mic'd intimacy come across as out-of-touch as Lucille Bluth asking how much a banana costs.

The callback to Parachutes' hushed whispers also means that Ghost Stories is the first time Coldplay has sounded explicitly self-referential. They're a band that's withstood enough comparisons to U2 over the years, and the warmed-over leftovers that have marked Bono and Co.'s last decade as a creative entity are enough to suggest that, if Coldplay continue to head down the path of addressing their own legacy, their best moments are truly behind them.

CS:GO - a game that will make you win-greedy.

CS:GO used to be a great game, always had fun playing mostly comptetitively.
It's a game for people that are looking to become really good into a game and like slow-paced gameplay.
Don't expect that being good in Overwatch will automatically make you good in CS:GO, since the gameplay is very different.
CS:GO, also standing for Counter Strike: Global Offensive has a long story of rise and (somewhat) fall. You will have a hard time getting out of the no-rank zone, where you must play with people that are first-timers, like you, or people that have 1000+ hours just warming-up.
Do not expect this to be a friendly game for people to relax. Competitive gameplay is just the kind of fun people have. And yes, you heard me right. People that play this game have more than a 1000 hours on it. I know people that have more than 3000 (some of which make a living off of this game). And this game does have lootboxes but worry not, they are just cosmetics that do not affect the gameplay in any way.
Some people also make a living off of trading. Which is also very advanced.
----------------------------------------------
How the game works and what you're expected to do:
If you're a newbie (noob), you might stay away from the competitive matches and learn how to:
~Strafe,
~Peek,
~Flank,
~Positions,
~Grenade shortcuts,
~Maps,
~Team build,
~Recoil patterns of various weapons,
~Crosshair placement,
~Team placement and 
~How different weapons behave and when to use which.

This might seem like a lot, but most of them are things that take about 10 minutes to learn, but of course, you have to practice them. And don't worry, you can play this game as a hobby.
Most of these stuff can be learned through YouTube videos, chats, coaches/friends, the community on Reddit, Steam and verious different websites or etc.

When you think that you are ready for competitive gaming, you will realise that most of the people you're playing with are kids or people that don't talk your language and have completely no knowledge of the game.
Most of the time you shouldn't worry, because you can also find good teams on special website to build teams.

After winning 10 matches, give yourself a pat on the back. You have reached your first rank! 
Silver 1.
Now, one thing that you should worry about in competitive matches are smurfs or hackers. This is why you should almost never play solo if you want to win.
Smurfs are people that have a higher rank, silver 5 for example, but play on a second account or intentionally lose to rank down so they can play vs. lower-skilled players.

Also, after getting through, let's say Silver 2, and you're now Silver 3, it's time for you to start warming up!
You can warm-up by playing stuff like Deatchmaches, or casual (the place where you started) or download maps from the workshop page. The workshop page is a place full of nicely put togheter maps for different purposes.
There are maps for learning how to Strafe, throw grenades or anything from above!
And of course maps for warming-up!

Community servers:

CS:GO is not jsut a standard shooting game, you can also do things such as surf, bhop or play various different mods, that can be found on the community servers.

I really hope that this review helped you decide if you want to play this game or not.

TOP 5 REASONS WHY WE LOVE & HATE CS:GO GLOBAL OFFENSIVE!

There are tons of online/video games out there and I bought a new gaming desktop 4 months ago, was wondering what kind of games should I invest my time into. And 3 months ago, I was introduced to this game “CS:GO Global Offensive” by a close friend of mine. At first, I wasn’t sure if I was willing to spend S$ 15 to play this game because I was never good at shooting games and I get frustrated easily if I don’t play well. And a lot of my friends are playing this game so I thought I could give it a try. After 3 months of playing this game, I have concluded on why people are addicted to this game and why is it so popular. Below are my 5 reasons on why we love and hate this game. 

-	Opening of Cases

When we ranked up in the game, it sometimes drops either great cases that we’ve been wanting or shitty cases that we wonder, “why is Gaben doing this to us” by dropping the same old cases. Whatever the cases that we ended up getting, we will always give in to the temptations and spend some cash in opening them. The sense of the unknown and hope often give us the rush of adrenaline, praying to all the Gods that we could think of and hoped that the line stopped at the items we want. If we got the items that we don’t want, we would curse and swear at ourselves for wasting time and money(again), also losing all hope and faith that Gaben is playing with us. And if we are lucky enough to get the items that we’ve always wanted or rare items, we would jump up and down from our seats or even running around the house as if we’ve won a lottery. Trust me, our parents will look at us like we are idiots. 

-	Condition and Skins of the weapon

Whenever we open cases we will always look at the condition of the weapon because no one wants a Battle-scarred weapon right?  Firstly, it doesn’t look new and “shiny”, secondly, it doesn’t have a high value on it even if you try to sell it (but depends on the skin though). Someway or another when we use an AK-47 even if it’s well-worn, we just don’t feel right. It’s as if we don’t get good kills like headshots JUST because of its condition, we know too well that it’s all in the mind. (You know what I am talking about.)
Weapon skins is also a very important factor in this game because if we get a very rare skin with the condition of battle-scarred, we can still sell it off with high value in the market. For example, Dragon lore AWP (Battle-scarred) can sell up to S$ 820 on Steam market! Besides this can be the only reason we can explain to our parents, that playing CS:GO for long hours is because we are earning money, right? 

-	Sense of Achievement 

Playing this game can be very frustrating most of the time, especially when we first started out. We were so bad and noob that we kept dying, being the bottom player in the team is not a pleasant thing. We all can relate to this all too well. However, being the bottom player is not the end of the world, this just means that we have to keep improving ourselves and play better. After hours and hours of investing in this game, we are bound to play better and when we realized that we played better than yesterday, that sweet sense of achievement is so satisfying. Of course, play and learn, in other words, invest your time wisely in this game.

-	Teammates

All of us know that this game needs 5 players to form a team in order to play a competitive game. It is very difficult to find teammates who can play like a team and whenever we find good teammates with great playing skills, we thank God or Gaben for the luck we had. But, there are days when we get matched up with teammates who are snobbish, arrogant or leaders wanna-be, it will be a game that’s full of stress and we will get pretty bad at the rest of the game. Let’s treat each other kindly, don’t be such a smart ass or jerk in the team.

-	The Community 

Putting aside all the game aspects, I dare say that the community is “The Heart” of CS:GO. You will never know when you will match with teammates who are jerks that are full of themselves and keep calling you noob, just because they have more kills than you. Or match up with nicest teammates who know that you are still learning, also willing to be patient with you and teach you along the way (VERY HARD to come by). It’s the community that make this game more addicting, because we never know when is a good or a bad match. If matching up teammates either spoiling or cheers you, then I have to break it down to you, “My friend, you are addicted to CS:GO.” 

If you are willing to take the risk of having blood pressure most of the time then maybe you can give this game a try. Welcome to CS:GO Global Offensive, Have fun and Good luck!

Over 2018 the game has improved tremendously, Updates included (1) Panorama, a new HTML5-based UI engine, (2) Trust Factor, a system that matches each player with other players with similar levels of trust worthiness determined by account age, frequency of reports and other in-game and out-of-game factors, (3) VACnet, a machine learning anti-cheating system that scans demos server-side and learns from Overwatch, and (4) Danger Zone, a unique fast-paced Battle Royale experience with CS:GO's gun mechanics and style.

Not to mention numerous new maps and map updates, gun meta changes, and changes to the way the major cycle operates.

Out of all of these Trust Factor was the thing that improved my experience in this game the most, frequency of toxic teammates dropped way down, cheaters are near non-existent (never encountered anyone who was undoubtedly cheating in my trust level) and the overall experience is a lot more authentic to what CS is supposed to be.

Overall this game turned from great to fantastic, and all the recent complaining about the game going free to play is pointless and a waste of everyone's time.

I mostly love this game because of the new COMPETITIVE mode. If you want to know more about it, read the first paragraph. If you want to know about every other game modes, read the whole review :).

With the Competitive game mode, Counter Strike became one of the most interesting, intensive and thrilling FPS game. Competitive game mode is about to play 5v5 matches with your team where you need tactics, skills and knowledge of the game, maps and spots. There are a maximum of 30 rounds / competitive game. The team that wins 16 rounds will Win the whole match. If your team wins, members of the team climb up on a virtual ladder. Winning more and more matches may get you better ranks by the time and with ranks of course, harder enemies in the future matches. When you are playing Competitive mode, every step, move and shot matters. A fault can easily loose you a round out of the 30 or a better shot or lucky move can get a win for you and your team. Even it makes pressure on you to prove your skills, you have to stay calm to be able to do your best! Play it with friends, make a clan, and create one of the best team or just solo queue for the matches you will enjoy the game (except when you get bad team mates with zero tactics). 

The second new game mode is Arms Race. Still you can select what team you are in, but it isn't really matter. There are Arms Race specialized maps (unfortunately only a few) where you start with an SMG and every kill brings you a new weapon. You have to be the fastest to fight yourself through every weapon and get a kill with every one of them. The last one is a knife (golden knife in this game mode). If you manage to get the kill with the knife before anyone else you win the match.
This game mode is fast-paced and excellent for some fun, and stress beating.

The 3rd one is the Demolition mode. You can play the classic game on smaller maps with only one bomb site combined with the element of Arms Race what means every round you get frag makes you jump on the next weapon in the next round.

Ofc there is the old game mode, called CASUAL where you play the classic maps with huge teams and there is a DM where you can select what weapon you want to play and then go and kill the enemy team members until the time goes down and the round ends.

I recommend this game for every FPS player. You can play DM or Arms Race if you want some brainless shooting, Casual or Demolition for short time playing/casual play ofc, or Competitive if you have more time to play and not scared for some team work, thinking and ranking ;).

So, after playing this game now for 2 weeks i want to share my expiriences with all of you. 

Pros: 

- The amouth of fun you can have with this game is insane. People started playing the actual mod for halflife 14 years ago and keep playing the game series.

- This game will be played for YEARS. Its not like other shooters develpoing new parts of the shooter every year. It has a fanbase that still is insanely growing and doesnt seem to stop.

-Should work on any Computer, because it uses the source engine that doesnt really need a super-expensive-awsume-hd graphics card. a normal one should do it.

-Interesting gameplay

-If you quiet have the skill you can make your own maps ( and release them to the workshop, that also goes for weapon skins. )

-Make Steamwallet-money by drops found ingame by selling them on the community market. These drops are mostly crates and skins, the skins can be used for weapons. They just make the weapon look different. That doesnt change it in any stats  like +3 damage. 

-It has a nice community ( No screaming CoD-kids c: )

--------
Pro-con:

-They game is cheap. Especially on the sales it goes for under 7€. But that also means Hackers can easily get a new copy of the game if their old account is banned.
--------

Con: 

- This game is something COMPLETELY else than games like Battlefield or CoD. in the defuse mode without respawn you dont rush in a little room with your MOAB and kill everyone for a hyperkillstreak to get a dog. You have to carefully sneak up to the enemy and watch out for footsteps of others. Not to say thats a bad thing, but you really have to get used to that.

- For newcomers ( like me ) its quiet difficult to get started. There are many players that already play since the mod was released 2000 and they got a really big load of knowledge that you probably dont. But with the time you get used to the basics of the game and then you can have fun.
You will die plenty of times. But you will get HOOKED.

If you want a game where countless seagulls bite and sting your face, then this is the one for you. Sometimes, it just gets out of hand and there are so many seagulls that even the best computer lags. I bought this game way back in 1992, when the beta was first out. This game started out as a mod for Grand Theft Auto:Chinatown Wars, but Blizzard Entertainment launched it as a full on game for Steam. This game has several guns to pick from. The infamous cannon, the slug-mug-tug, and few others. If  you are lucky, there are crate drops that occur once a month and you can buy a key from the In-Game store with 5,000 microsoft points. The worst possible unbox you can get is a knife, so if you get a knife, then put it on the market for $0.03. That's what I sure did.
Somehow, I don't think "TERRORISTS WIN" blaring through my speakers at an airport is grounds for "random screening."

One day I bought this because it was on sale for about $2.50. I didn't think much of it but then I started playing. I couldn't believe how addicting it was. I started losing sleep and skipping meals. It started to show on my physical health. My family started bugging me about it and even considered putting me into a rehabilitation center. Let's just say they won't be bugging me anymore. But now I dont have the funds to maintain an internet connection. I've sold everything I have just to play. I can't even go to starbucks and use their wifi because I sold my clothes and apparently they dont accept nudity. So basically I'm writing this review from my phone on top of a bridge. My life isn't worth it without this game. Yet it seems to have ruined my life. Goodbye world.

CSGO is a near-perfect multiplayer shooter. Unlike the previous versions, which were often difficult to get in to, this one offers a variety of modes that will appeal to all skill levels. It has a large community and a well supported workshop, ensuring that this discount-priced game will be around for years to come.

In short, you either play as the good or bad guys and must either kill the other team or complete objectives to win the round, which will earn you more money to do the same thing again but faster. It's been around for years and has spawned many imitators.

The game isn't much of a looker as it is based on the same engine as the original Half Life 2 was. However, Valve have polished it as much as they can and the community consists of lots of awesome mappers who have been churning out brilliantly imaginative and beautiful maps almost on a daily basis.

Is it worth getting if you already own Counter Strike: Source? Yes. CSS was always Counter Strike shoe-horned into the Source engine. CSGO feels far more like a standalone game. Valve have very carefully listened to what people have wanted and have made a very appealing game. The best feature must be the competitive play. You cannot leave these matches or you'll suffer a temporary ban from the feature. After 10 wins in this mode you'll be ranked and will be paired up with people of the same skill, meaning that the game is challenging but fair regardless of your skill level. These matches are exciting, occasionally scary or frustrating, but are the most rewarding part of the game and improving your rank is one of the most satisfying experiences in any video game, ever.

There are all kinds of teams and communities that you can join. Really, if I was stuck on a desert island with one game this would most likely be my top choice. It's bigger than you can hope to conquer and has a huge community around it which will likely be around for years to come, something that can't be said for the Call of Duty franchise which is probably its closest rival. Remember that those games are full price and have another one churned out each year, fragmenting the community. Plus you can customise your weapon skins in CSGO. Surely that's the most important feature?! All they need to add now are hats and you might as well live in CSGO.

If you expect awesomley thrilling SP campaign - No. you cna play with bots. but the gameplay may seem "outdated". It is nostalgic, not outdated. It has taken some of the best FPS game features and compined it with CS 1.6 and CS:S. great competiteve excperience. Servers sometimes might not be the best for competiteve experience, but there are some free, better server alternatives. You will not like the game if you expect something like huge map invasions like in Planetside 2 or BattleField series. it has awesome team play elements, hard controlable gun recoil. Sir, we just dipped under 40 trillion in net worth, we HAVE to revive a old IP!  That's right folks, buckle in, we have a journey ahead of us! 

Hi everyone, Welcome back to another installment of Valve Software Review! I'm your host, the Flynn of the week. 
Well hello everyone, today we will be reviewing Counting-Strikes 3, locally known as "Count-The-Strike-Global-Domination". Before we dive in, we need to learn a little about the earlier installments! 

Back in 1999 we had a little game called Count-This, your classic shootem up mayhem blaster game. In Counter-Stride it felt like you were floating on ice, shooting water from a pool noodle, all while taking in the 3 polygon atmosphere of the original 2 maps! (dust 1 and dust 2) This is what made counter-man so unique in its gameplay, make the player nauseous constantly, and it excelled at this immensely! 

Winning gamer of the year, the old lard you've come to know and love, Grab newell, wanted more money! In comes Counter-Strike Source(material)! A lot of time, Effort, and of course big pink cookies, went into this installment! You could now shoot your f***** gun and it would actually shoot this time! Outstanding! Counter-Strike Scourge broke new grounds in shooting gameplay such as:
Controlable guns
No more ice on your feet
3 more polygons(total of 6)
But this wasn't enough for the old man, he recognized there should be more to a shooter...

In comes Cooter-Strike 3!!! You play world renowned country singer John-Shootman! Featuring many innovations, improved gun mechanics, HD graphics, realistic recoil, this game had it all! Not only did it have all these wonderful additions, but for the first time Counter-Strap was now Team Fortress 2! Weapon skins! Stickers! Mechanics from old games(p*rnsprays) now behind a paywall! Did i forget to mention $500 biker gloves? But that STILL wasn't enough for that old geezer! Fortnite gamemode, 5 year coin for buying the game! Don't forget Free-to-Play! Unfortunately Gab newsell in his time of darkness, sold out to the chinese, adding in Chinese Bootlegs(Sexon Zombi) and censored graphics. No longer could you kill your opponents, only arrest them. Sad! Counter-Strike continues to live on with every piece of garbage they throw at it, after 7 years this game is still played and loved by many. Even virgins. 

All in all, the C*nt-Striker series has been a up and down rollercoaster, filled with laughs, giggles, and gaggles. Game of the year 2(not 3) years in a row, Counte-Strike stands the test of time, because they keep updating it with microtransactions. Gabe newell would be proud. 

-Flynn Stoe

I consider myself a little stubborn when it is about games. Long ago I was a Quake player that never thought CounterStrike would be a game to play for real. Time proved me wrong and I ended up being part of the competitive 1.6 scene. The game conquered my heart and I got totally hooked.

I'm posting this review for level XP. This game aite.

During the CS:GO Beta I would have told you this game was an amazing addition to the CS lineup.. The game was designed to handle 128tic, and the official servers were hosted as such.

After full release the game was still great, and they added competitive matchmaking with a ranking system. This was the only gamemode I played for a long time.

Over time, the official server hosting seemed to be contracted out to a third party, who clearly saw cutting corners instead of buying more or better hardware / bandwidth as a pheasable option. The servers went from 128 to 64tic (this means how many updates per second between client/server, basically time resolution for movement/gunshots)..

In CS:S everyone was used to writing an autoexec to ensure their cl_interp_ratio was 1, and their cl_interp was 0. This is to ensure you are synced to the server. The command cl_interp_ratio is a ratio or devider for how many "tic" or "updates" per second your client will transmit and recieve. Valve decided in an update about 1.5-2 years ago that they would make the default cl_interp_ratio 2. Add that to the 64tic servers and everyone is now at a 31ms delay vs the 7.5ms delay the game started on.

Everyone can still have a 15ms delay vs their default 31ms, but 99% of players now do not know how to change this... so even if you change your own, it doesn't do a thing unless other players are set correct as well.

Now... The next thing, I don't even really want to talk about. Skins? At least it wasn't hats I guess. I don't use them, I think most of them look like MS paint given to children.. and it's more than sad people will pay the money they do for some. Free steam games for the people who could care less I guess.

I only recommend this game to someone who enjoys all the things I apparently despise, or if you can ignore them and just see the game behind the bullshit. There's also always the option of not playing on the 'official' servers, and there's lots of 128tic pubs. Not sure about scrim servers, but it's very very simple to set one up yourself with SteamCMD.

Nach 1,2K Std. In diesem Spiel muss ich mal meinen Senf dazugeben.
Wenn man dieses Spiel beginnt zu spielen wird man oft die P90 oder die AUG benutzen, desto länger man es spielt desto mehr findet man gefallen an der AK, M4A(und/oder 1).
Ich bin jetzt schon Master Guardian Elite und muss auch dazu sagen das es sich einfach gut anfühlt wenn man einen neuen besseren Rang erreicht hat.
In CS:GO erkennt man auch seine Fortschritte ziemlich gut, man steigert sich einfach jede Woche.
Man verbessert sein AIM, seine Reaktionszeit und und und.
Leider gibt es auch Leute die sich das Spiel auf einen 2ten Account kaufen nur um andere mit niedrigerem Rang zu besiegen, die sogenannten "Smurfer" die können einem das Spiel wirklich versauen.
Im Winter/Summer Sale kommen viele Hacker, aber zum Glück gibt es ja das "Overwatchsystem" im Overwatch werden die Reporteten Hacker von der Community angesehen und am Ende wird entschieden ob sie gehackt haben oder nicht dieses System schaltet man ab den Rang Gold Nova und min. 50 gewonnenen Wettkampf spielen frei.
Durch die Workshop Maps kommen noch ein vielfaches an verschiedenen Spielmodis hinzu z.B.: Surf, Deathrun etc.
Falls man noch 3€ auf seinen Steam Account hat, kann man diese in einen Schlüssel (2,50€) geben und eine von über 15 Arten der Kisten öffnen und beten das man etwas gutes bekommt.
Mein Fazit ist, wenn man keine Lust mehr auf ein CoD oder BF hat sollte man sich für 15€ dieses Spiel holen, wird am Anfang eher nicht so Spaß machen dafür aber später ;), es sorgt außerdem für eine sehr, sehr lange Zeit für Beschäftigung.

So after playing Counter Strike for about 1 year now and putting over 1000 hours into it, I thought I would make a little review. Throughout the time i've played I've seen many Good/Bad changes made to the game. I still think some of the changes are a little stupid but I've come to get used to it. Although there are a lot of cheaters I still manage to have fun. Whenever I encounter a cheater I just laugh and mess around with them, because it's funny to think people would waste 15$ on re-buying the game for multiple accounts to cheat on. I was recently reading a reddit post by a proffesional CS:GO player by the name of DaZeD in where he mentions a way that can reduce cheaters by a mass amount of numbers. He basically stated that CS:GO should add a system so that the first 50 queues are unranked so the cheaters would basically be going against other cheaters. He also said that after you finish the first 50 queues you can start playing for ranks and start playing on 128 tic servers. I agree with all of what he said. This was originally going to be a small review and it turned into a little over a paragraph. If you actually read all of this and have any opinions leave a comment letting me know, and I'll try to get back to you.

Folks, I'm a man of simple pleasures. I like the PP-Bizon. I like going zoom-zoom. I could write an entire review about this instrument of death but, let's get back to the game. 

CS:GO is missing something that it had when I started playing that I always enjoyed. It breaks my heart. I also pity you if you don't know what I'm about to complain about but, ignorance on this issue is pure bliss. 

I myself miss this change more than any particular map. I miss it more than any-particular buff/de-nerf. I miss it more than a previous competitive rank on a de-rank. Yeah, I went there. 

It's also admittedly something I hope for more often than I wish for Valve to fix its MP servers or crackdown on cheaters because apparently that's too much to ask. 

So instead, I'm just going to directly ask Valve in this review. 

They obviously read player reviews considering how much folks love them, right? Right. That's what they're doing instead of improving this game (right, Valve?). 

Valve. My request is a simple one. And I know I'm not alone. You can take my money but you took something from me that belonged to me and only me. I want it back.

Global Offensive is the latest franchise in Counter Strike. Awesome new layout in the main menu and the same goes for the buy screen when the start of a match. After each match, the weapons that you are currently using will be load up on ammo automatically. There are several new weapons in this franchise, so...you can look forward on using all the weapons. Another thing that is new in this game will be the weapon camos, I am not 100% sure on how to get this....but from what I've heard from my friends...you can keep on playing the game until you unlock new camos in-game or you can make your own unique camos in the Counter Strike Global Offensive Workshop. There are 5 modes in this game: Demolition, Arms Race, Competitive, Casual and Deathmatch. Counter Strike: Global Offensive. A big step from Source and has become big enough to actually have a title in the large industry of video games. 

I will first start off with why this game is amazing. I find that this game is the closest thing that you could get to a raw skill video game. You start of with a weapon and the only way to get better with it is to practice. It is not like Call Of Duty which basically gives you a weapon with only vertical recoil which you compensate for by pulling down. I am not saying that COD is bad I am just comparing it to give and explanation on what I mean for a raw skill game. This game includes recoil that goes horizontally which you have to compensate for by learning the spray pattern and compensating for with mouse movements. Either it is spraying or tapping which for me at least is much harder because you have to be patient and shoot accurately.

 The idea of competitive is amazing as it gives a point to all of the gun action and killing which some people seem not to justify. It changes how you would play a first person shooter by including the ability to plan enemy attacks, seek out what their economy is like or if it is a fake. All of these things involve skill and play time of the game to learn what each of these looks like. Adding to the competitive mode the ranking system is also a great idea giving players the ability to work for something and accomplish something with all of those wasted hours infront of their computer in a dark room which in great detail describes my summer vacation. It gives a sense of being the best or overpowering your friends which is always fun because everything seems to be a competition nowadays. Competitive mode is just one of the reasons many people love Global Offensive over Source because back in Source and 1.6 it always just seemed to be a casual game with much more people. I was never able to play Source or 1.6 back in that time because I was never introduced to CS but from other people who have stated their opinion this is exactly why the love Global Offensive. 

And the last more important good thing about CS:GO is the map choice (Only including Dust II, Mirage, Cache, Inferno, Overpass and Train which are the main maps. Sorry Nuke, I still love you!). You have Dust II which is everybody's favourite map because of the balance, Mirage because of the unique strategies and simplicity of the map, Cache because of the interesting layout and the many skill based movements involved in the map, Inferno because of the quick pushes you can initiate, Train because of the vast change in the map in a short time and my favourite, Overpass because of the interesting layout and the close sites. All of these maps are perfect for competitive play because they are easy to learn and are just maps that everybody knows. 

And now this games problems. I personally have never really a proper toxic player but maybe that is because my trust factor is high and the plan that Valve have created is working. What I find to be the main problem with this game is the lack of updates. I know creating a game and keeping it up to date is very difficult to do and who am I to say update this game? The reason this is a problem is because giving an update to a video game keeps people playing the game with new content and fixes which might have caused problems before. Valve is currently working in Panorama UI which is a welcome change so they do have a reason not to be making any update but in general small updates and fixes (just like the neck hitbox update!) will keep the community happy because they know it is one less problem with the game and you saw how happy the community was when they could finally shoot at somebody from behind and count as a headshot. I am saying that this is a problem only because of the immense amount of money Valve is making from cases and skins and with that sum they probably should be able to keep their game up to date. I have never really played Dota 2 so I am not sure what they are doing with that game but they seem to be doing good as the player count is quite high. 

The "problem" with hackers make me feel like people just overreact. I am going to get a lot of hate for this but I have never met a blatant cheater who is spinbotting or using bhop scripts to jump around the map. When I say never I mean it, even in casual or deathmatch I have never met a blatant cheater before. I just feel that people think somebody is cheating just because they are a smurf or just much better at the game. I only reported around 5 players in my entire play time  (because my team wanted me to report them)  and none got banned. I just feel that because people wanted the fairest game possible and just to win they freak out when they see somebody that it better than them. Maybe I am just blind to cheaters but when people just think a good player cheats it really doesn't feel right. 

All of that a side CSGO is definitely still one of my favourite video games and it is still amazing even with all the community complains about. And that was my little review on Counter Strike: Global Offensive and I hope you enjoyed it. Sorry for any mistakes, English is not my first language. :)

CS:GO is a game which was once designed around team-based attacks and defenses, something which has since been replaced by weapon reskins and recoil patterns.

Pros: 
¤Very easy to hop into a casual game and enjoy a quick game.
¤Very easy to join a competitive game and work with a team of nearly equal skill-levels in a longer game with higher tensions.
¤New game modes to choose from.
¤Wide variety of powerful weapons at your disposal.
¤Betting scene.
¤Numerous competitive leagues and teams for highly skilled players.

Cons:
¤Difficult to master weapons and recoil patterns.
¤Luck plays a considerable role in fights.
¤Learn a plethora of new insults from teammates.

Conclusion: For 15$, it's worth every penny.
this game is nice

The FUTURE of competitive gaming. I expect to see every family playing counter strike together within the decade. Families gathered around the telescreen, waiting for that last final clutch. The father fires one shot from his polished AK, it's wooden gloss glinting in the sun of the map of the year. The shot rings out, from the speakers of the telescreen. In that moment, the son contemplates his life's future. He sees a happy family playing by a white picket fence, his arm around his young wife's waist as they plant the "SOLD" sign on the front lawn. The daughter sees her prince charming, as they walk down the aisle together into an endless union of love. The father sees his glory days from college, the boys in his frat, and the touchdown pass he made his senior year. The mother sees herself with the young football star she fell in love with, two young mavericks against the world. The shot hits home, the match is won. The family hugs, their joy clearly visible together. They climb the stairs to bed, and prepare for tomorrow's activities. Tonight was just another normal night, but together they've all experienced something they'll never forget together. As you lay in bed this night, picture that scene in your mind's eye. You, your happy family all gathered to enjoy the future of competitive gaming. That's what Counter Strike Global Offensive was made for.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive may have been released in August 2012, but the impact it has had on the FPS genre and gaming as a whole, is still prominent today, and is unmatched by most other games.

Firstly, the game runs incredibly well. Despite not managing to match the graphical fidelity of some other big-budget titles, for the most part, it still looks "decent" and the visuals will not be an issue whilst you are playing. Although it is still running on the old Source engine, it does not look very dated. Perhaps this old engine is what enables the game to run so well, and the added frame rate is hugely beneficial to your gameplay experience. It is one of the only games where I am able to fully utilize the potential of my 240hz monitor.

Valve's many years of expertise with the Counter-Strike series mean they have a lot of experience in creating fun gun-play that has vast amounts of replayability, and this is extremely apparent. Each fight feels different, even if you are playing on a map you have experienced hundreds of games on. The Design feels extremely polished.

In a competitive enrivonment like Counter-Strike, the ranking system is important. The system, in this case, means that ranking up is not too hard, nor too easy. If you are too good for your rank, you will rank up within a few games. This was apparent as my skill increased, as I was previously stuck in silver for over 2 years, before ranking up from Silver 2 to Gold Nova 1 within 3 months. 

The Valve Anti-Cheat seems to be quite effective in preventing cheaters from becoming widespread. Whilst you may find a cheater every now and then, I have not encountered many in my 481 hours played (at the time of review). It is also worth noting that, in multiple instances, my reporting of cheaters has led to neccessary action from Valve, and this must be commended.

Counter-Strike is also strong in the Esports department, and this has never been more apparent than in CSGO. You feel the same intensity that you would as a player, whilst spectating a match on twitch. The success of Esports in CSGO is apparent with the many viewers it collects during tournaments (especially majors).

In conclusion, my many hours in game (though not as many as lots of other people) demonstrates the quality, and replayability of the game. I may not ever get bored of CSGO, because the game keeps drawing me back after 3 years. Whilst CSGO is not perfect, it comes very close, and is without doubt one of the greatest FPS games of all time.

Final Rating: 9.5/10

Before I start, I will admit, even if I once was a hardcore first person shooter player, I kind of got tired of them over the years. I had Counter Strike Source and Day of Defeat Source, but I pretty much only wanted them for Garry's Mod. The last CS I played for hours and hours was the 1.6 version of the original, and that was over 10 years ago.

Now, after these Summer Sales, I saw CS:GO at 5€. Looking at other "mainstream serious FPS" these days, like CoD and Battlefield, that usually go arround the 60-70€, not counting the fuckload of DLC's, it seems like the best deal ever! It actually is?

The awnser is, yes. Oh man, I do still suck a bit at these games after playing nothing but TF2 for when it comes to FPS games, but I still had fun like the old days. The game is done to perfection. Guns work as intended, no stupid recoil like the recoil you see in other shit FPS games, here it looks realistic, and it feels good. The maps are good as well, feel just like the originals, while the new ones add originality, and the ones made by the community are always amazing. The gameplay is smooth. Right now I'm using a shitty PC, since my old one kind of blew up (it probably could not handle my afro), and this piece of crap runs the game without that much issues on low-mid settings, while games like CoD Ghost or Hardline always bring dumb problems because of horrible optimization.

I have like 30 hours so far with this game, and I bought it on the Summer Sales, that ended like a week or two ago. I have been in normal servers, filled with both new and old players, I have tried bots, and I have played 10 matchmaking games so far, and without counting the MM match where I ended with a bunch of Russian assholes who did nothing but to yell crap on their microphone, blame me, and then ragequit, I had nothing but fun. And that's another thing, the community is amazing. Some people might stay silent most of the time, but they won't get THAT mad, unless you really screw up something, or act 100% retard (like dropping your gun at the start of the round, buying nothing, going 1 vs 5 with your knife, and then say that this game is a bad ripoff of Call of Duty. I have found one dude like that, and I think he was not trolling, but totally serious). And well, I did fuck up at times on my first matches, I wasn't used to the new buy menus, the changes of the maps, the new models, I find of teamkilled 2 friends so far, but they where not mad. Probably because they where new too, at some point, and know how it sucks to be THAT guy.

The sale is over, and it doesn't cost 5€ anymore. Still, the full price is like 12€ or so, and if you really like competitive and serious multiplayer FPS action, this is your game, doesn't matter if you're a filthy casual, a nooblord, or the classic "MLG" that will probably kill the other team in 30 seconds with 5 bullets, all headshots.

Oh, and while the weapons feel balanced, I got to say that the shotguns are really underrated. Further more, I f#cking love them. It might be because I'm an old-school Unreal Tournament player (I have been in tournaments, and shit), and my favorite weapons from that game was the Flak Cannon, but I find it fairly easy to kill scrubs who tryhard with M4's and AK's with 1 or 2 shoots to the face, while they crouch and spray their bullets all over Mordor. Give them a try if you're new, you won't regret it. If you don't believe it, look at the screenshoot below, at the end. I played nothing but classic pistol rounds and Nova the whole game, and I ended up with 43-18, being the MVP of the match. And I'm not that good, you can probably do it way better than me! Besides, killing 1 player with the Nova gives like 900$, while weapons like the AWP (best Sniper Rifle) only give 100$. What's not to like? And if in the end you find the game boring, just idle on servers. With time, you will get drops and items that you can easily sell in the market. With some time, you will get your money back. I have gotten 2€ so far, just with the new crates, so...

I thought this would be easy, but who knows I thought this was just like regular MM. Then we got 16-0'd. I couldn't turn a corner without getting rekt. 
     Time went on and I found myself with 20$ on my steam. I got 2 normal Global Case Keys and opened 2 cases. Whatever it was, it was shit. Anyway, I got an AWP | Pit Viper, an M4A4 | Urban DDPAT, and a bunch of other crappy stuff.
     This would eventually turn into an addiction. I got my friend knife. A Flip Knife | Scorched (FT) I was so happy. Then I got scammed when I learned what a "Blue Gem" was. My shitty blaze pattern AK-47 | Case Hardened (FN) I overpayed a shit ton for. But I was happy, and GabeN soon would be too.
      I went on to be given a Karambit Vanilla from a friend, and like, I still had my AK and everything. 
      I worked the next summer for my father. I earned over 500$. Now if you look in my inventory, its all their. Actually now that I think of it. Its way more than 500$.
      Long story short, This game is very competative and I get Salty (NaCl) all the time. My Highest rank (As of now) was Supreme Master First Class. After the new Update I'm currently LE and probs gonna be back to Silver IV soon.

A worthy update to Counter-Strike: Source, CS:GO improves upon tons of mechanics that were lack-luster, or made the game too easy to get good at in it's predecessor.  I think it's clearly safe to say this game also removed the stain left in the professional Counter-Strike community after a few CAL judges made unnecessary bans to advance their teams through tournaments.  It's already had almost  two dozen torunaments with multiple professional 5-man teams that many may recognize from CS 1.6.  This game made quick work to fix some things that were decidedly annoying in CS:S, one being the too-often consistent bullet patterns when not on a flat surface(e.g. jumping, surfing, et cetera.)

Some guns have been removed(looking at you MP5, and M3.), although they have been given replacements, and are joined with other new weapons that make the game much more fresh, and keep things interesting.  Overall, combining this with the skin updates that will now be regular, the game can even pay for itself within a few weeks!

The features allowing you to download demos of your games, watch the pros and casual high ranks alike live, and tons of exclusives for watching tournaments not only brings up community morale, but increases the excitement of the game.  You can also link your twitch account to make it all easier.  Very cool.

Community servers are surprisingly still full, and almost as numerous as the last 3 games, even though Competitive play has been enhanced with an ELO system, and ranks to go along with it.  Like always, if you can get good at this game, you'll be good at any First Person Shooter, making it a key title to own and play.

It brings a set of new graphics that are amazing to compare to the other CS games(nostlagia withstanding), made all the better because of Valve's typical work to offload Graphics Processing to the CPU when possible.  For what it's worth, it hardly tolls even low-end GPUs like my current 525M, with maxed settings, and very high levels of  Anti-Aliasing.  I'm able to keep a minimum of 80 Frames Per Second, and average about 150.

All in all, I'm pleased to say that I have over 600 hours sunk into this game, and am only about 200 hours off surpassing my CS:S playtime as of writing.  Valve did an amazing job with this game, and I can't wait to see what it's successor in Source 2 will look like!

First of all, I'm sorry for my english, it's not my native language but I wanted to do this Review in english for more people to understand it ^.^

It would be quite difficult to count up positive and negative things in this game because it all depends on who you play with!
For Example the voicechat - It is one of the most important things in CsGo Matchmaking! Making calls for your teammates often are deciding  whole games (if you do them correctly), BUT there often are some people trying to be funny and just scream random stuff in their mics nobody can understand nor use as information.

I wouldn't say the Community is bad in this game, there are some really nice people and I also made some good friends by playing this game or trading ingame skins. But again there are some a**holes just being jerks.. Blocking players in the Competetive mode on purpose for example. But hey, those probably exist in any kind of Multiplayergame and we need to deal with them.

The VAC-System. VAC really is a good AntiCheatSystem, but nobody ever will understand that it is impossible to detect every cheat and as soon as there is one little cheatercunt with no balls, the people need to blame VAC.
As I said, I do not think it's bad, but in my opinion Valve should definetly think about cooperating with other Anticheat-Systems to get rid of more Hacks.

I can't tell you a lot about the gameplay itself. For my part I play the game for fun, of course I try to climb up the ranks and try to reach the Global Elite [GE], but mostly I'm just surfing around (Surf is an inofficial gamemode which already exists for quite a long time on private servers - I won't tell you any more about it, if you want to know what it is you can just search for it on youtube/google) with friends.

I'm not a professional player  at all and I also gotta admit that I started with Global Offensive which means I can't tell you a lot about the development over the years, but during the one and a half year I'm playing this game a lot of amazing Updates came up which made the game better and better.

I hope I'll be able to experience a lot more Gameplay-improving Updates which also make the game better!



Thank you for reading! c: (If anybody even read all of it :'D)

When I hear FPS, I think of Counter-Strike, The game that other shooters wish to be and try to thrive in it's C☺CK SHADE!
If your new to this game and want to progress, start by playing Gun Game and Casual.
Practice on custom aim maps to help you on your quest to improve your overall skill. If you just want to have fun with it, then so be it!  

Competitively this game takes teamwork, dedication, endurance, consistency, map knowledge, nade placement, counter-strafing, mouse tracking and imhuman reactions!
If your still using a ball mouse or a crappy laser mouse, f☺cking forget it, don't buy and install this game, all your tears will turn to wine! At it's core CS:GO is a skill-based competitive shooter. 

Continuous updates, bug fixes, operations, community made maps, weapon skins, stickers, 
map-editor, etc etc, it has longevity and will keep you coming back for more!
Personally I have a love hate relationship with this game, when losing really sucks and winning will send shivers through your shaft. Whether it may be, getting a 4k or even an Ace in a comp match! Missing an easy shot on an unsuspected opponent, only to get dinked by a 180 flick-shot and losing the match! This game will always be a staple in the FPS community and on the competitive scene.

[h1]Basic Information[/h1]
Title: Counter Strike : Global Offensive
Developer: Hidden Path Entertainment and Valve Corporation
Publisher: Valve Corporation
Genre: FPS Shooter 

[h1]General Impresion[/h1]
Like the previous games in the series, Global Offensive is an objective-based multiplayer first-person shooter. Each player joins either the Terrorist or Counter-Terrorist team and attempts to complete objectives or eliminate the enemy team.

Players purchase weapons and equipment at the beginning of every round with money awarded based on their performance. Completing objectives or killing  enemies earns the player money while negative actions, like killing a teammate or hostage, takes money away from the player. In addition, when a round ends all players receive some amount of money, with players on the winning team receiving substantially more. 

Currently, Global Offensive features five game modes for online play : Classic, Competitive, Arms Race, Demolition and Deathmatch. For competitive mode you need to reach rank 3 by playing in other modes. 

In my opinion, CSGO is the most realistic FPS Shooter that I ever played.

[h1]Strong points[/h1]
+ Great AntiCheat
+ Great ranking system
+ Great animations
+ Great gameplay
+ Great optimization
+ Team-based
+ Objective
+ Multiplayer
+ Steam Trading Cards

[h1]Weak points[/h1]
- Fewer maps
- Operations

Many years ago I was drafted for this war. I was in the most deadly battle you could think of. I had lost all hope of survival and my team was loseing left and right. Then in my darkest hour I saw something that inspired me to keep fighting. It was single chicken that ran by and then I was inspired to fight for my freedom and I died but then I came back into the world.
I think the reason was because I had not completed what I had started, I had not shown honor to the chicken yet, but then I saw a group of chickens and thats when I saw the holy chicken the one that I had saw in my time of darkness and I talked to it and became friends with thy chicken. The world of Counter-Strike has changed much since its inception as a mod for the original Half-Life, but its core has largely remained the same – until now. [i]Counter-Strike: Global Offensive (CS: GO)[/i] has done away with one official game play mode and has added a few more to spice things up.

Classic modes remain, but they now come in two flavors: Casual and Competitive. A popular mod created for [i]Counter-Strike: Source (CS:S)[/i] was “Gun Game”; it’s now here and called “Arms Race”. Finally, the newest edition is a mix of Classic and Arms Race, called “Demolition”

[i]Counter-Strike: Global Offensive[/i] features eleven pistols, six shotguns, eight submachine guns, eleven assault rifles, six sniper rifles, two machine guns, a knife, six kinds of grenades, six pieces of equipment, four game modes, fourteen standard maps in competitive matches, and an integrated matchmaking system, tournament viewing system, statistics tracking system with leaderboards, and inventory system that allows the player to collect weapon skins and other items that result in cosmetic alterations and no gameplay alterations.

The game is still using the Source engine but this doesn’t mean that it hasn’t received a major overhaul in the graphics department. The graphics in [i]Counter-Strike: Global Offensive[/i] are in a realistic style. They depict an Italian village, Middle Eastern villages, an office, and other locations, plus weapons, players, and weapon skins, some of which are in bright neon colors like pink or blue. The sounds include footsteps that players make when running and not when walking or crouching; gunshots; and the voices of characters that say things like “throwing a flashbang” and “throwing smoke.” The music is orchestral in style and alters dynamically based on what is occurring in the match.

Players in have one hundred health and can be killed with three or four bullets from many guns, or fewer if the bullets hit the player’s head. Players can purchase armor to protect their body and a helmet to protect their head. This allows players to survive more bullet shots from some guns. Other guns, like assault rifles and sniper rifles, can kill players with one or two shots whether or not the player is wearing armor. Players run faster if they have their knife or sidearm out. Guns dropped by dead players can be picked up by other players and the game notes who the weapon originally belonged to in the spectator screen. The models of the characters alter depending on the map that is being played.

[b]THE GOOD[/b]
-Large number of maps
-Replayable
-Numerous weapons

[b]THE BAD[/b]
-Steep learning curve
-No single-player campaign

Coloring inside the lines was not only unacheiveable but I had to watch the coolest kid in ELL Eli Chubin do every day. It wasn't fair I wasn't like the rest of these kids I could do 20 pull ups! If the principal wouldn't advance me to regular classes I would have to it myself. Using the problem solving skills that landed me in ELL I devised the plan to kill every other person in the class because then I have to be moved up, I mean they couldn't have a class just for 1 person right? I searched online to find out how other people did mass murders and it seemed like the most efficient way was with shooting the place up so I decided that was what I would do. I didn't know where to start though so I searched online once again to find out how all these murderers started. I quickly learned that it was violent video games was the thing that all these murderers had in common so I decided that must be the thing that makes killers. CS:GO (Counter-Strike: Global Offensive) is an (Online) First Person Shooter game.
The game is very similar to the other Counter-Strike games out there, but this one is special,
it has new maps, new types of play style, a great community (edit 2019, also a toxic community) & of course skins.

It's basically the type of game that you could play for hours and still never get bored of it
(thanks to a growing community, new maps etc.)
This game isn't a hardcore ''MLG-Pro 360 No Scope'' Simulator like Call of Duty
This is basically an awesome game. (edit 2019, not really that awesome)

Now to the part why you should buy it..

As I wrote before, you could play for hours and still enjoy it.
This game is not too expensive yet not too cheap.
It could get expensive, if you get into buying skins and such, but that's just your choice.

GAMEPLAY:

Gun sounds are good you could recognize every gun, and pretty realistic. (Atleast in my opinion)

Sound quality is good, especially if you have good quality headphones. (Footsteps etc. is good to listen to for improved gameplay)

Aiming and such is very diffrent to other games but is easy to master if you change your crosshair and your sensitivity to what you like and feel comfortable with.
________________________________________________________

Overall a very good game. Worth the money.

9.8/10

Last but not least, i have to point that the cs go community is likely the worst.

Still, worth buying.

After being around CS since the olden days, back when we had WONIDs and such...this is a drastic change. In a good way.

I still kept playing 1.6 for awhile, even after CSS was released, my PC couldn't handle it, but I was more than satisfied with what 1.6 had to offer. Once I upgraded my PC and was able to jump into CSS, it was nto what I..expected. It did not go over well with the way I had gotten used to CS 1.6. I stopped playing CSS and went back to 1.6. 

I got into the beta of CS GO once it was announced, tried out ok: Ok, seems to work like 1.6, but with CSS visual..this is nice.
The game actually plays very well, it does have some drastic changes from what we <1.6 vets remember. I think Wayne Campbell said it best: In many ways it's superior but will never be as recognized as the original.

It's a great step up from the original, take the first step, I know it's frightening, but trust me, you'll like it.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, or CS:GO for short, is a highly competitive skill-based game. This is what makes it so great, learning the maps, all of the different tactics, improving your aim and managing the economy. This however, can be a long grind. Every map has its own calls, grenade spots to learn and positions to play.

CS:GO runs great (although every updates costs FPS), has some great design, and decent graphics for an older game. Updates come regularly to add stuff (Most of the updates are skins and other things, but that doesn't make the game bad) and Valve keeps improving the game. A big downside of CS:GO however is the big amount of cheaters. If you don't link your phone number to the game and play in "prime matchmaking" the game can be literally unplayable. This can be very frustrating, especially when you're doing your best to rank up and improve. 

Aim and sound play an important role in CS:GO, more than in most other shooters. Every gun has it's own recoil pattern to learn and it's own unique playstyle. Since CS:GO requires a lot more tactics than most other shooters, aim also very important. Having your crosshair at the right position means you can take your opponent down faster. Lots of practice, playing aim maps, helps and using your sound to locate your enemy's footsteps gives you a big advantage. The CS:GO e-sports scene is also massive. Millions of people follow it and it's a great place to learn. Use this to your advantage. Want know those new tactics, boosts and smoke/flashes? Watch some games! You can honestly learn a lot from watching the pros play. 

Now of course, you saw this one coming, the community can be really... annoying. Especially at lower ranks, the community is full of toxic kids, people who have no idea what they are doing and teammates who refuse to work together. This can be harsh, especially because CS:GO heavily relies on teamwork. That's why I recommend playing this game with friends. The faster you're out of those low ranks the better! Once you get a bit higher you'll see the community gets better and better (with the occasional toxic/clueless player of course). People work together, people give useful information and are just a bit nicer to work with in general.

Next to competitive, CS:GO also has some gamemodes for people who just want to have some fun and don't care about ranks or tactics. Gamemodes like: Arms Race, Deathmatch and Casual are great for this and the thousands of community servers offer cool things like: surfing, aim training, roleplay, minigames and more!

Now, would I recommend CS:GO? Sure! Especially for the small amount of money it costs. Just don't expect this to be another casual shooter. It's a highly skilled game and requires you to put in a lot of time to improve. Pick this up with a couple of friends so there's less of a chance of having these annoyances.

“Easy to learn but difficult to master” is a phrase thrown around quite a bit in gaming, though less so in video gaming. Counter Strike seems to fit that idea pretty well. CS is lean. CS:GO is the embodiment of what made CS good, with clean, updated graphics and a couple of new modes, but little of the basic formula has really changed.

There’s something to be said for a game that knows what it is and executes that idea well. Between the refined quality of classic CS, and the new tweaks and modes, there is plenty here to warrant a $15 price tag whether you have played CS before or not. CS:GO is hard, hardcore, and still a blast to play.
