CoD and The Other One fanboys need not apply! (Unless you want to).


Pros: It's fun. It's more serious than your average shooter, with spray patterns, carefully-thought-out-on-the-fly-tactics and whatnot and it needs you to keep your hand in on a regular basis. Not the prettiest to look at of it's kind, but it's nowhere near ugly and it makes up for that in other ways. Wide variety of maps - both original and fan made - to play on. Lots and lots of things to practice with, ranging from Bot matches to actual fan made training aids. Mechanics (such as the aforementioned spray patterns for each weapon) involved. EVERYthing needs to be thought out and practiced on - from PoE (points of entry) to how you're going to get best usage out of whatever weapon you are holding at the time, even to how you personalise your mouse settings! Even the training is fun (mostly). Possible to make (lots) of money playing this game (if you're lucky). Achievements are wide ranging - ranging from easy to damn near impossible without luckand they DO encourage you to play with different weapons, maps and styles. Medal system as well as rank. Mission based coins to purchase for extras.

Cons: Due to the way it's set up (with fair reson behind it), a noob can get lumped in with absolutely anyone in matches - which could pit you with: people around your level of ability, people WAAAY in advance of your level of ability and complete £#@&tards (strangely, the game never seems to put you in with people lower!!). Playing with people can mean you end up playing the same maps over and over and over again (which is good for learning, but can be a pain, especially if it's a map you don't particularly like) LOTS of training involved. A personal con (literally) for me is the money you have to spend to get keys to open chests. Not a lot, but it all adds up (and also increases your chances of finding a valuable weapon to sell for REAL £££'s!! Which sort of turns it into a Pro - dependant on viewpoint)


The cons could put a lot of people off, but let me just say this - I pretty much at fps's. I don't really play them much and even then they tend to be things like the bioshock/half life/fallout/dead space type of shooters rather than your hardcore Call of Shouty or Battlerage (sorry for the dig, console peasants, mwahahah!) but if even I, pathetic as I may be at these games can have lots of fun, then the game must be doing something right.

If you love CoD and Bf to death, stick with those. If you fancy chancing your (shooting) arm on something a little more serious, OR, if you're an ARMA fan, why not give this a shot (pun intended). It'll either broaden your horizons, give you a bit of a challenge or be a nice diversion from your normal shooter of choice. Or all three, as is my case, old and crap as I am.

One last thing I will say is that this game has cracked time travel. I start at say around 9pm and then, after only a couple of matches, it's half past three in the a.m!! Also....  {that's TWO things!}

Two last things I will say, is that the game has cracked time travel and if you feel that things aren't going your way (i.e a bad round or two, or you can't find any enemy) then my advice is to take a 20-30min break - HOWEVER MUCH YOU DON'T WANT TO - trust me, it helps!

For those of you who're new to the Counter Strike series, this game has been around longer then any Battlefield or Call of Duty game. Most commonly known to now as CS:GO, this game has been around since 2012 and the previous one, Counter Strike: Source since 2004.

Counter Strike Global Offensive features a sufficient amount of gamemodes such as Demolition, Hostage and Defuse missions which actually require teamwork and co-orindation to win. CS:GO has its very own competitive play system which you're placed into a 5v5 match of people the same skill level as you (which is determined by your ranking on official VAC Secured servers) to fight it out on a gamemode and map of your choice. 

This game isn't for people who like to give up easily, it required skill in knowing the maps, how to handle recoil and working as a team to achieve victory. I'd highly recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a challenge in FPS shooters.

CSGO is a cultural icon, it is valve doing what valve does best; making timeless classics. The game has a good formula i.e. it is easy to get into but difficult to master and this constant need to master the game is what keeps you going. The game is no stranger to criticism or bugs of which I will cover in this review.

The new inclusion of battle royale and change to a free to play model is quite welcoming actually despite the large community backlash. I like to think of this update as WarOwl said in a recent YouTube video; CSGO is like a water park, you have your Olympic sized pool for all the grownups (competitive classic CSGO experience in this case) however you also have to cater for the kids with some cool visually good-looking water slides (Batlle royale in this case). It’s not like Valve is forcing you to play the BR mode, and to be honest it will never replace classic CSGO competitive, it’s just a bit of differentiation. The mode from first impressions seems good with it’s classic CS gunplay incorporated, however it is quite concerning that your fps currently drops significantly when playing this so maybe consider lowering your in game graphics.

The change to free to play is a bit questionable on the hand. Due to the influx of players and no need for a monetary investment there will be more cheaters and I am unsure if valve has the best anticheat to stop this. I however think that most cheating will happen on non-prime due to the grind that’s still there to get to level 21 and get prime status. From a personal experience so far I haven’t encountered a cheater actually in over 3 months (maybe because I’m Legendary eagle?) which is a great improvement however with the large influx of players I am unsure what will happen, I guess we have to wait and see.

People say this is a dead game, all over forums and game sites you’ll see people complaining that valve shows no love for the game and that its support is lacklustre compared to the likes of dota 2. This is true to an extent; sure, valve isn’t updating CSGO every month with new revolutionary game changing mechanics because they tried this with the r8 revolver update and various nerfs to which the community responded with fierce criticism. Truth be told valve has made a surprisingly balanced game and making and huge changes will drastically affect the classic counter strike gameplay we as players have come to expect. Some guns can be broken such as the one hit potential of the awp and ak47, and at first you would think that you can never reach that level but with a little practise you’ll realise that you were flaming over your opponents for no reason.

The player base can be disappointing at times. I would highly recommend making friends on this game as it will drastically help you become a better player as solo queuing is a coin flip, some day you might get the best teammates you could have imagined for, other times you could be stuck with a team of people from all corners of Europe raging at who’s baiting who via their abomination of a microphone. Toxicity is a big problem with the game along with smurfing and frankly it’s just something you get used to, my advice is just to power through it, you will have some bad games but there is a shining beacon of global elite at the end.

From my review you’ll probably see all the criticisms and must think I’m crazy to recommend the game, to which I should agree however there is just something about this game, whenever I turn my PC on I instinctively boot up CSGO and next thing I know I’m in a game having fun just like that. I have over 1000 hours in the game which is dwarfed by the amounts some players have put in, you would think that’s more than enough time to bore someone of a game where you realistically play the same 7 maps and use the same 5 guns most of the time, but it doesn’t. I think it’s the fact that you can see yourself progressing as a better player, you will learn to spray, learn to clutch and gradually you’ll look back and have a sense of accomplishment which in turn activates a drive to play more and become even better.

Counter Strike is back, with CS: GO – Counter Strike: Global Offensive – the newest line in a decade of first person shooting games from Valve.

I must start off this article by saying that I first played CS (Counter Strike) when it was a beta. It was a mod for Half-Life that my friends and I loved playing on sweet 64MB Ram – 256MB of ram powered computers. Counter Strike, Day of Defeat (years later), EverQuest for them and Dark Age of Camelot for me. My childhood friends and I loved the games that we could get our hands on because they were all the best at the time. Sometimes we would spend our boring lunch hours as freshman in high school at Futureshop checking out the games we were going to buy and play. We played on DSL and cable connections and for the unfortunate of us that were still in internet yesterday – 56k dial-up lines. That’s when AOL was pumping out CD’s in the mail of free copies of their dial up software for every Tom, Dick, and Harry to use.

We were nerds in our very early years and you could say we were very young gamers. We did have computers but we had to get our parents to drive us to LAN parties most of the time. Sometimes, a group of us would ride our bicycles or walk to each persons house and help carry back computer components. We’re not just talking mouse and keyboard combinations. We’re talking giant 17-22″ CRT monitors that weighed 25 pounds or more.

I mention all this because back then we were just grateful to play video games. We felt a privilege that our parents didn’t know and probably would never know. We could become submersed into any fantasy world that we wanted and do whatever we chose. What was even better was that we could do it in an online environment with our like minded individuals. Or at least individuals with a common interest in that particular video game. It was amazing what we were able to do so we didn’t troll, we didn’t grief, we just played our games. When they became boring and we became overly skilled that was when we knew we could get away with some TKing action and still complete a level, or a little friendly fire that leads to a failure of a match premature to a failure that was likely to occur a few more minutes down the road.

This leads me into the era of video games today. Our precious game that became dominated by hackers and impossible to truly know how good you were because you never knew if the person on the other side of the internet was looking through a wall at you has been remodeled. I say remodeled because I feel as though that is the extent of it. The game’s graphics have been improved and polished and the game includes many new features. It’s new in game features make Counter-Strike Global Offensive an easy game to play with friends and a fun game to watch if you don’t feel like playing. However the underlying problem is still there – you don’t know what the person on the other side of the internet is doing. With the game running $4.00 over Christmas it was a steal and I wish I had bought it for all of my friends but I didn’t think about it at the time.

The problem and it may change in the future is that Valve will never have a way to secure their games. They update, the hackers update, as with the world of technology. Back to the game itself though because I do not wish to take away from its positive qualities.

Counter Strike Global Offensive is available through steam. The game allows you to play as a terrorist or a counter terrorist in many online matches. There are hostage rescue, demolition, and arms race maps. I never checked to see if my all time favorite – THE VIP MAP!!! – is still around but I’m sure there are some servers still running it.

The game is now centered around in game skins which are sold by other steam players in the marketplace, are won randomly in game, or purchased through steam itself. I can imagine that steam is making money hand over fist with these new promotions and their addition of the in-game trading cards. We will never know though since they are a private company.

So Counter Strike? GO. Go should stand for Go Buy it. Even if the game is still riddled with questionable players, it’s still fun to play with friends and still as highly addictive as it was for me 14 years ago. So if you’re peddling your bike to a LAN party, sitting at home drinking by yourself or doing illicit drugs, put down $4.00 – $20.00 for this classic game and relive some old time memories.

Overall rating 8/10 Based on the game, mechanics and memories it was able to conjure up. It lost points for a poor match making system and no way to leave a game without being penalized in competitive mode. This makes it a 45 minute grief session if you get paired up with a bunch of griefing or annoying voiced kids on your team.
BEST GAME EVER!!!!!!

If you enjoy the FPS genre, do yourself a favour... Buy this game.

The developers haven't created a new game. Even though Global Offensive has some small innovations, it's mostly an adjustment of a well known game to today's standards. After a few hours I felt some kind of relief, that Valve kept the good old CS intact, but then something hit me. There are no radical changes – only a very obvious lifting, and this series is in trouble. CS:GO is a great game only because the original CS is a great game. If you're not a fan of this kind of gameplay, don't buy Global Offensive – it offers nothing more.

The true successor to 1.6. VALVe really went out of their way to make sure this game came out the way it did, catering both to the grizzled ancients and newbies alike. The engine feels just right when it comes down to firing your weapon and landing the shots, if not rewarding, but expect to be punished for careless mistakes as it always has been on the series in general. The skill ceiling is a high one, as expected, but the game does its best to prepare you for online play with the increased range of difficulty levels for the bots (with 'casual' being nothing short of a shot gallery rather than an actual bot match) as well as the general course; this last one I think works as more of an introduction to the series than an actual tutorial for those already familiar with the basic game mechanics. While I still remain iffy about the introduction of microtransactions to the series, I think VALVe has done it just right by limiting your purchase of skins to the marketplace (a completely optional feature of Steam in general) and, of course, their infamous "crates" first featured in Team Fortress and relabled as "Cases" for the sake of consistency with the in-game universe. 

As always, Counter-Strike isn't a game for everyone, but whether you're a veteran to the series or just interested in seeing what the fuzz is all about and make a first break into the games, I highly recommend CS:GO.

Also, I apologize for my incessant use of run-on sentences.

I honestly don't understand the mentality of people who have hundreds or even thousands of hours in this and now want a refund. You payed $15 for literal days worth of game while there are plenty of people that will pay $60 for maybe 20 hours worth of game, like are you kidding me? The worst ones are the people with the 5 year veteran coins and like 500+ hours. Why should you even have the right to be refunded at that point? That's like buying a toy and having/using it for 5 years then returning to the store and saying "Well now you're just handin' em' out so gimme my money back." It makes absolutely no sense.

Do I feel cheated? No because I enjoy the game and now the people I've always wanted to try it can on their own profile. I can finally have a team to play with, not that I don't like playing alone (clearly given the playtime.)

Is this a bad update? Yeah, it is but at least it's a separate gamemode and not core game changes. 

Would I rather have things like more new maps, an operation, or server upgades? Of course, any of those would have been 10x better but Valve is company and the choice they've made makes sense from a buisness standpoint, which is to attract new players to revitalize the community and more importantly to them, the market.

Should you play it? I enjoyed it as you can see, so of course I would recommend it, especially since it's free now. Just understand that this game is complicated and not for beginners to pc fps or the fps genre in general, it will take a bit of time for you to properly learn this game but I think it's worth it.
It's k, I guess..

I made a review long time ago, but I try my best to rework this and tell a honest opinion about this game.

So Counter Strike: Global Offensive is a FPS game, where 2 teams fighting with each other on different maps / gamemodes. This is prefered to play online. This is well known franchise, also a well known genre, the online shooters.

So, graphiclly this game still on point. Came out in 2012, the game changed a lot, but still looking pretty much good.

Sounds and music is also all right in the game. You can customize the music in the game with music kits, atleast it makes less boring after some time.

Controlls are nothing special either, works fine, and you can customize it.

Is it worth playing this game? Because I hear lot of hatred about this game, either because of the toxic playerbase, or cheaters or both... is it worth playing? I have more than 3000 hours in this game, I have this game in my library since 2015 and I can tell you, if you enjoy the game itself from the beginning, not bothering about the previous said aspects, then yes. If you just think about this game, just as a game, you won't have a problem.

Well, it's a bit complicated now, like it was 3 years ago for example, because of the trust factor. For me, I have okay matches with legit players and I have no problem, but for someone, who just started to play this game, will have bad time to play in non-prime. This is why I really don't like this game atm, new players hardly can join and continue playing this game.

Lot of people also raging about the skins, cases which are coming non-stop, and "there are no good updates". If you dob't like skins, then ignore it. About the fact, that we don't have 128 tick servers or Source 2 engine... well, do we really want that? I mean, what would have been if we got it? I don't mind it, but I'm okay with game right now.

You can be better in the game everytime you play, and you can keep playing it to time to time, but remember that it's much better playing in a team, with players who you know. I recommend to play with friends or find others in the game, who are okay to play with, because you don't want to get into a team with full randoms, who sometimes can't even talk in English (not everyone).

Basically, this game is like a cheating girlfriend... you know she is cheating on you, you start to avoiding her, even you broke with her up, but you keep getting back to her. This is the case with me in this game. I'm not a good player, if we compare how many hours I have, but I still like to play this game, helped me a lot in different ways, and I met lot of nice guys through in this game.

This game is like that one abusive relationship that you was in. You come home with whatever bit of your soul is left just to get yelled at with words and languages that you have never even heard before. You try to argue with the game and calm it down, but it keeps yelling back at you in gibberish and even hits you once or twice. Slowly, but steadily you grow some sort of ignorance towards the game. "Fine" you say, "I will just mind my own business to not anger it anymore." This feeling slowly creeps in more day by day. Whenever you get abused by it, the feeling gets stronger and stronger until you finally break. You shout back at it. You say mean things to it. You try to make the game feel bad. It feels good to relieve all that negative energy that built up inside of you over the span of all these hours that you was abused for, but then you start to wonder: "When did I become this toxic? Is this really me?" You start having an existential crisis. You leave the game alone for more and more time. First minutes, then hours, then days and finally months and years go by with you not caring about it anymore. Until one day, it jumps into your mind again. You can't forget about it. And be sure that the day will come, that you will try it one more time with it.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive (CS:GO) the newest addition to the Counter-Strike franchise supposedly takes the best from both its most famous predecessors, Counter-Strike 1.6 and Counter-Strike Source. I as a person who has played 1.6 for approximately 8 years cannot confirm that wholy, but I can at least say that the game is fun to play, with the biggest advantage it has over it's older brothers being the matchmaking. I would easily pay Valve $100 for 1.6 with the matchmaking from CS:GO. But that is not gonna happen so for the time being I just have to settle with what CS:GO offers.

I might have sounded a little more negative than I wanted. The graphics are nice enough even though well aged Source engine, although with the newest tweaks, cannot compare with latest AAA production. Apart from new look you will find your all time favorites from previous Counter-Strike games, same goes for weapons and game mods. However there is not only an old content. You will find couple of new guns and what I appreciated most were new maps created by community and published in buy-able packs by Valve providing the creators with part of earnings.

Later on the game suffered an attack of "dropable" content. Fortunately Valve did not step over cosmetic changes, so you can only spend your hard earned bucks on different weapons skins, at least for now.

This is a great game and in fact one of my favorites. It's a game focusing on tactical strategy, not just run and gun. If you are the king of person that likes run and gun, there are other gamemodes like deathmatch and arms race (gun game) or you could go with tactical things like casual (search and destroy) or competitive (very serious and tough search and destroy). It's a tough game but one of the best ever. Although it's really fun and a great game you need to watch out for some things. Things you need to be very careful about are: 
        Cases. My gosh Valve has to make thousands off of people buying case keys. You will get rewarded cases in games for free, but to buy a key is $2.50. That doesn't seem like much but you'll probably only get skins worth less than what you paid for (yes people pay momney for skins make sure you don't pay too much either.) If you don't care how your gun looks in game you should just sell the cases on the community market. It's okay to open one here or there but the moeny adds up fast. And don't worry you'll get gun drops too.
         Skilled Players: You will rage so hard when you KNOW you hit someone ten times in the heart and did 597 damage but it only registers 3 shots of 23 damage to their arm. People that are skilled are, well, skilled. I guarantee you will get mad at this game at some point. If you want to be paired with people with equal skill play competitive.
         Competitive: When you play competitive there are 30 rounds each 3 minutes long (if you tie the whole game) and you have to accept not to quit the game for the whole length of the game, or you won't be allowed to play for 30 minutes, then 2 hours, then a day, then 7 days and so on if you keep quitting. If your game crashes or something you have three minutes to get back in the game. To avoid this (if you have to leave or something) you can ask your team to kick you. Some don't cooperate but it's always worth a shot.
Now that seems like a whole essay on why not to play, but after all, it's a great game and one of the best first person shooters I've ever played. It's unique, it's fun and it's about teamwork. Don't fall prey to it's clever buying oppertunities but other than that you're fine!

Totally the best game ever! This is not just a fps game. The guns have recoil, which means the gameplay becomes more realistic. The story is the same as source or 1.6. There are terrorists and counter-terrorists. The terrorists plant a bomb or guard hostages and the counter-terrorists try to defuse the bomb or save the hostages. It is also an awesome game for traders, because you can trade the in-game weapons. Highly recommended for everyone!
Best Counter Strike ever

Best tactical shooter out there and its popularity is a proof of it. It takes thousands of hours to get your movement, aim, and gamesense to (almost) perfection.
People who play other games usually use the argument that the game is not realistic because you can't ADS but a game should be played to take you out of the real world, otherwise you can simply go outside...
CS:GO keeps being updated after 3 years of its release and it will keep getting better. And i'm not talking just about graphics, which are great and not heavy at all for your graphics card.

SKINS
At this point in time it's obvious that skins are a huge part of cs:go. Me and some friends o'mine have made hundreds of dollars of profit trading/betting. Others have been scammed/lost they're bets/bought cases, but anyone mature should know how to manage their money correctly.

SUMMARY
If you can get past the first few hours of hell, you'll get addicted for sure. But remember kids, DON'T GAMBLE. Oh, and learn how to speak english.

Valve's Counter-Strike: Global Offensive (CS: GO) debuted in 2012, backed by a strong heritage of multiplayer FPS titles, including the original Counter-Strike and Counter-Strike: Source. Now, six years later, the fast-paced PC game still mostly holds its own against more modern titles, partly because of its established core gameplay and active community. Visually, however, CS: GO is starting to show its age and it's not as thematically rich as other popular titles, such as Overwatch. Still, many players will enjoy CS: GO's no-frills experience and competitive scene, especially now that it is free to play.

So, how does CS: GO retain its prominent role in an industry that has diversified considerably since 2012? A big part of its success is due to its massive esports following. It's always among the top titles streaming on Twitch and Mixer, and it benefits from a well-established (and financially lucrative) competitive scene. The game even includes a dedicated Watch section so you can follow and spectate tournaments.

ADVERTISEMENT


CS: GO is now free to play after a recent update. Its previous $14.99 cost was not expensive, but this price change opens the game to an even wider audience than before. In comparison, Overwatch costs $39.99, Player Unknown's Battlegrounds (PUBG) costs $29.99, and Ubisoft charges $14.99 for the Starter Edition of Rainbow Six Siege. Fortnite is, of course, free as well.

If you're lucky enough you can get rare items dropped, which you then can sell on the market. Go idling, milk the cow, if you're lucky you'll get an awp skin. Or a knife model. In that case, you can quit your job and lay back.

A very complex gunplay system makes for extremely realalistic fire fights. its a change of pace from BF3/4 and COD but it requires more skill to play then ether of these games, this will lead to a higher tiers of playing. Although the ranking syatem needs an overhaul for the competitive mode as it is based on wins and not individual score this can often lead to mis ranking you to lover or jigher tiers. 8.5/10

I have a few things to say about this game. Firstly, and most obviously, it's free. I've got a bit of a bad history with free games: I have been scammed and they are often just not that good. However, CSGO is just as good as when people paid for it. My only complaint about it being free is that it introduced a lot more hackers into the game, especially in the lower levels. This obviously isn't very easy to deal with, but it can make getting out of the lower stages of the game more difficult than it would be otherwise.

I also really like how well balanced the guns are. The AK and M4 are still the main rifles, but there are other great alternatives that are well worth the price and still give you the bang for your buck. My only complaint here may be (very small though) is that after the Krieg and the AUG were nerfed, they still remained the most expensive CT and T sided weapons apart from the AWP. I understand why as scoped rifles are OP but if there is any case for making them cheaper it would be great to see the price go down by $100-200.

In my opinion, most of the current competitive maps are great. They are all designed very well and lend themselves to multiple types of tactics. One thing I would say is that they are all very CT sided, and the team that starts CT always has the upper hand. As well as this, get rid of the hostage maps. Seriously. Office and Agency are both pretty awful in themselves, and they are breeding grounds for hackers. No serious player actually enjoys these maps.

All in all tho I have really enjoyed this game and I would recommend it to anyone who wants to play a good FPS

*Edit after another 2000 hours of playtime:

There are many ways in which we can find CS:GO frustrating to play. Biggest problems (at least for me) to overcome were hackers and seemingly random ranking system in official matchmaking system. Other people get annoyed by toxic players, griefers, smurfs etc., but let's be honest, as long as you play any multiplayer game on any platform, there are always  people that enjoy seeing others in pain or anger.

Luckily, there are ways to solve all issues mentioned above. Third party platforms (Faceit, ESEA, Esportal etc.) are growing bigger than ever before after CS:GO became free to play and hackers are everywhere on matchmaking. Although their anti-cheat software systems are not 100% hacker proof, the amout of hackers is substantially lower than the amount of hackers cruising uncertain waters of matchmaking. Paired with their decent raking system there is one last problem these platforms are yet to solve - toxic players.

For me, it is not that big of a deal. There is always an option to mute and report that one annoying teammate screaming slurs in foreign language, but for a big group of people it does not solve the whole problem, since your experience is already ruined. On Faceit, that group of people is called ECL. ECL consists of many hubs, each having their own join requirements (required Faceit level, hours spent in-game, number of games played on Faceit, etc.), so no new accounts can't join any of their hubs. There is a caring admin team, always opened to help, willing to kick toxic players from ECL hub and always trying their best to make sure you have a good time playing CS:GO.

So after all my time spent playing CS:GO, I found my new home at ECL hubs. For me it is the best place to play CS:GO since you play on 128-tick, anticheat protected, decent ranking system having servers and in a hub, where all rules and admins make sure you can calmly click heads in this glorious game with an insanely high skill ceiling we all love.

[h1] REVIEW OF THE REVIEW : [/h1]

If you never played this game, then this review is for you.

Counter-Strike have been on since early 2000's when steam didnt exist.
Ive been playing this game ever since. This game is probable the best competitive game ever created. 
The way you play the game with your teameates, 5 vs 5, in matchmaking is so satisfying. A 30round ( 16 best match )
with Terrorist VS Counter-Terrorist playing for a full team elimination or a bomb explosion. This game is from far the best FPS shooter game ever made. This game is not for everyone, it takes a while before you can actually be good.

The strategical way of playing each round with the adversity, elements and the surroundings of maps, creates all kinds of ways to eliminate, counter, juke your opponent. The game has so mutch content to learn that even today I keep learning new stuff. There are so mutch ways to get better, by practicing by yourself in close maps with bots. Learn new flashes, smokes. And i can go for hours.This game is a TEAM game in wich you need to always communicate every moove you do, everywhere you look. Know how your teameates plays. The best way is to play with your buddys.


I will try to not get deep in the game when explaning because it can go for hours, so here are the basic stuff you need to know about this game.


When you will start playing this game for the first time, you will cry, scream, be inrage. You might brake your computer in pieces. Here is the tip for you : you will need alot of time configuring the game at first before starting playing it, 
for example ; Getting the good sensitivity with your mouse, choosing a good crosshair, ajusting your graphics ( I would recommend everything on low except for shadow quality, THIS IS A FPS GAME ). 

Learn your sprays with :

- AK
- M4 / M4-S
- ALL SMGS.
- AWP

Once you've learned the basics, you can try to hop on Match making but still will have lots to learn again.

[h1] This game is all about those 5 facts : [/h1]

[list]
[*]YOUR MOVEMENTS ( The way you moove in maps, jumping, cutting corners, bhop, perfect peaks. )
[*]YOUR AIM ( Sprays with guns. )
[*]GAMESENS ( The way you play when using your brain can have a big advantage. )
[*]TEAMWORK ( Communication is the key to moove up in ranks on matchmaking. )
[/list]

[h1] Now here are the bad stuff about this game : [/h1]

[list]
[*]Community is so toxic its unbelievable,
 i mean you can probably get kick in a game for not doing what they asked you or su cking really badly. ( at low ranks ) This is a problem for some people but you dont see it that often.

[*]Vavle is su cking everyones money with skins, and all kinds of crap to buy ingame. It doesnt change anything if you have some or not. Please dont feed Valve.

[*]When you get higher ranks ( gold nova to legendary eagle ) you will go threw lots of hackers, people leaving games,
trolls, or just people that suck at this game. Thats why i recommend playing with your friends is the best way to enjoy it the most.

[*]When you think your good, your actually bad, you can always get better and there always be someone better than you.
It can be frustrating but actually that is what a like about this game. It is all about the person in the back of the screen.

[*]Vavle never release updates to help the game it self, ( hitbox, anticheat, ect ) Like i said Vavle is a money machine.

[*]This game has a really fast paste, it is not for everyone. Some people have played for years and are still very bad at this game ( even if they think they are good ).
[/list]

[h1] IN CONCLUSION : [/h1]

I would recommend this game to everyone that loves shooters, If you can play with a couple of your friends.
There are LOTS AND LOTS OF good times and fun.

Picture this. You can hear the cars outside, your laundry machine is making noise while you casually strut down de_dust2's curvy parts. Suddenly, silence. Your whole team is dead, you are left with your expensive ak47 skin, 30 bullets and a dream. The world seems to hold it's breath, watching you spend every expensive second on the clock, trying to get a grip on a situation that all your team sees as hopeless. Your brain tries to block out the noise of your russian teammates, discussing how they will f**k your mom if you fail. Comforted by the fact they've pretty much done it with everyone's mom, you keep going. The light sweat starts pearling on the left side of your forehead as you drop down into ct spawn, warming your hands with the flesh of an afk player. Knowing you've revealed your position, you hide in a little corner looking left and right as you can feel the imminent danger. The clock ticks. Determined to never let anything happen to that ak redline, you soothe it with comforting words as you casually press the inspect button, showing off your stickers. You realize there is 20 seconds left. The sudden adrenaline makes you forget about the walking key. You start running like a rhino towards A site, knife in hand like in 'survival tips with rambo'.  The chills penetrate your spine as you hear the sounds of an autosniper in the background, but you keep running. Finally, you reach the bombsite, you check the time and you see there isn't enough time to plant the bomb. You gulp loudly as you fall back to your senses and prepare for the incoming ear rape of your teammates, a bunch of underrage homeschooled squeekers. The silence returns, but only for a second as the whole team votekicks you, pulling you back to the homescreen. Your eyes start to blubber as you feel that, deep down, you did deserve it. You close the game and launch a game of minesweeper to forget the tough times that you have just endured.

There are two ways to review Counter-Strike: Global Offensive.

The [strike]easy[/strike] Silver way, and the [strike]hard[/strike] any other rank way. First off, I'll start with the Silver way.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a good, low cost game, that is often featured at the top of Steam's top seller list. However, be aware, the price that you are paying when you initially hit the purchase button is not the games true price. You [i]will[/i] spend more on this game. Just like when the Counter Terrorists face the Terrorists - this is not a time for negotiation. Get your/your mums credit card ready, because it's going to be used. 
 The first thing I bought was a single key. I got a case drop from my first game, and I thought that the £1.49 investment would be meaningless. I was wrong.
 I was lucky enough to get an M4A4 Howl, in the "Minimal Wear" condition. Pretty lucky, when you consider that the current price for it is around £250. It wasn't at the time, it was 10 times less. I still sold it, and invested in more keys. Before playing Counter-Strike: Global Offensive I had no idea what it was like to be a compulsive gambler. I do now.

This isn't the end though. Before I played this game, I enjoyed speaking to people of different cultures, and nationalities. Now, however, I have a burning rage inside me whenever I discover that somebody is from Russia. I'm just glad I finished my A Level in Russian history before I started playing this game. The Polish are a sort of wildcard - some of them you love; they are friendly, helpful, just like your local plumber. Some of them though... You know that they are down the job centre whittling away your paycheck by claiming benefits, then using the computers there to log some hours in CS:GO, to push through smokes, and to buy an AWP in an eco round. You know you shouldn't hate them - everybody makes mistakes, but you are in a blind rage.

You need to win. You need to get out of the Silver ranks. You are now in too deep - you are in the "other ranks" stage. You feel you need to prove that you are better than everybody else. First the silvers, you criticise every mistake they make. Even if they aren't Silver... they are now. You rise up the ranks - Gold Nova I, II, then III... you get so close to Gold Nova Master... that fourth star... but before you know it, you slip. You're falling down the ladder... you don't know why. 

People believe that Match Making is a pit. It is not a pit, it is a ladder. Many who try to climb it fail, and never try to climb again. The fall breaks them. Some who are given the chance to climb high refuse - they cling to their rungs, their Master Guardian IIs or their Legendary Eagles. They are content with not believing they can go higher.

Only the ladder is real, and the climb is all there is.

Be warned, once you start climbing, you must keep looking forwards. On the way, you will learn much about yourself - that you have an innate ability to shout curses in foreign tongues, and that you can go weeks without eating as long as it means putting another hard earned sterling towards getting that god damn Asiimov. You will doubt the ability of all those around you, just as they will doubt you. Some days will be good, some bad. Some are easy, but many are hard. You will cry, but you will enjoy every moment of it.

You will make friends and enemies on the way. Children, boys, girls, men, women. Some you will love, many you will like, and even more you will hate. Often you will close your game hoping to ravage a beautiful Norwegian girl, other days you will want to take up arms and burn down entire Eastern European nations. There will be plenty of salt on the way, and it will be used for many different things. You will bury it into the earth, so Russia can no longer sustain life, freeing up valuable space in the EU servers. Often, you will become the salt, as you can no longer hold in your anger - yet you must realise the truth. It was your fault. It was your lack of skill, or your poor reaction time. You're just having a bad day. Many will not admit this, and seek to blame others - on this day, they are the salt. 

Once you begin, as I have mentioned many times, there is no stopping. Many people believe that there are many "Counter-Strike clones". There is actually only one. Counter-Strike: Source and Counter-Strike 1.6 are nothing like Global Offensive. The only game that comes anywhere close to representing Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is, in contrary to popular believe, Katamari Damacy. This is because only Katamari Damacy represents Global Offensive on a wider scale - a ball that gains momentum, and keeps growing. You cannot stop the growth. You can't stop, for the ball has grown too large. You reach a point where you are unable to stop your balls from stealing your money, and sending it to a small country thousands of miles away. Your balls give you hatred towards minorities, and towards people who are of not only a lesser skill level than you, but a greater one. Your balls keep growing... until you get to the top.

When you reach the top, you will look back and question yourself. Was it worth it? Should I have alienated my friends? What do I do now? What is that smell? When did I last feed my cat? Where should I bury him? Is it too late to get the game refunded?

* 10/10 * I'm addicted. This game is so much fun. It's great to play with your friends, easy to learn, and has multiple features that keep you coming back. There are five differnt game types, so there is always something you can play. Even if the game types get old, there is custom, where you can play user made maps, with endless different types of things to do. Something really cool about it is that there are two versions of the main game, competitive and casual. In casual you can practice and it just for fun, with nothing ever being saved. In competitive, wins and losses affect your points, the higher points you have the higher rank you get. People in competitive hope to one day make it to Global Elite, the highest rank possible which very few players ever make it into. Another interesting thing is skins, and using the market. I can't really explain that, so you will just have to play and see. I don't often give a perfect score, but this game is a 10/10.

The thing that causes people to hate CS is because of toxic people, before you have a greater trust factor, hackers, and also griefers. All of that can make some people rage (Me included), and that's why it's better with friends, CS:GO is a great, it's community isn't.

The Counter Strike franchise was introduced to me by CS:GO. Several friends of mine were constantly playing so I decided to buy this game. One of the best decisions I've made! This game is the best competitive fps out there and one of the best fps games. It's not a game where you play to unlock guns, attachments, scopes etc. The only thing to work foward to is getting better. This game has a pretty big emphasis on death because the fact you live once per round and you must buy guns at the start of a round, you do not spawn with them. This game also has a huge emphasis on strategy. There is strategy everywhere from how to defend bomb sites to where you plant the bomb on the bomb site. There are two competitve gamemodes: A bomb scenerio and a hostage scenerio. In bomb scenerio the terrorist are trying to plant the bomb on site A or site B and the counter terrorist are trying to stop them. In hostage the counter terrorist are trying rescue the hostages while the terrorist are trying to stop the counter terriost. Both gamemodes are fun and require strategy and map awarness. The competitive match making system makes it easy to hop in with friends or your clan and find a match fast with eneimies around your skill level. The gameplay is very smooth. The shooting mechanics are one my favorites parts on this game with a pretty big emphasis on recoil and headshots compared to other fps games. A downside to this game is the visual element. It's not bad it is playable just not the best the game could look seeing how it was released in 2012. Counter Strike has a decent community most people are open to new players and will give them tips to help them out. I highly recommend this game for people who enjoy competitive fps games. If you enjoy this game you will most likely find yourself pouring countless hours into this game to improve your skill. I rate this game a 9.8/10

It was a pleasant discovery to see the Counter-Strike mod is still if not the most popular technical fps shooter 20yrs on. I tried CS Source some time back and to me it felt like a clunky update from 1.6, just didn't have the smoothness or the glide 1.6 delivered, idk maybe my hardware wasn't up to scratch and I should revisit it simply for the retrospective comparison. This is where I feel CS:GO shines, it really feels like a smoother, much brighter and updated Counter-Strike over the predecessor while maintaining all the sounds and goodies that make Counter-Strike such a great team game to play. The main improvement however as CS and weaponry always felt good in game is the networking social aspect of it. The integration with steam, matchmaking, trust level and player rank really helps a more balanced and equally challenging experience online which is what makes CS:GO competitive in a fun or more serious sense if you enjoy that. Counter-Strike:Global Operations also has a couple of new fun modes such as arms race a type of top fragger deathmatch scenario that changes your weapons as you progress, demolition maps, new fun scrimmage maps, scout wars and casual modes. Once in a blue moon Valve will also release a special operations challenge which are weekly missions to obtain certain medals. I missed the last one which was called Operation Shattered Web and we all anticipate the next one as it kind of takes away the repetition of playing the same maps and level types.

Moving onto some negatives. Be warned as a new player and not having unlocked the trust recognition or prime in CS:GO, the servers are plagued with cheaters and unless you pay upfront for prime you will be matched up with no history accounts and more so likely trolls and exploiters. No matter how many times Valve release an update and anti-cheat, trust enforced boot of CS:GO such as the one back in mid 2020 for example. This release disabled by ability to run FRAPS (an in game frame rate overlay) tool. The update felt promising but within 2 matches there was already someone using exploits and cheats in the game. They either use them upfront and are totally obvious or they are losing rounds and toggle them on. Valve have incorporated and invested a fair bit of money against cheats, lots of servers and overwatch admin to help combat the problem, but it does not fully keep up with the rate of disgruntled and new cheaters out there. There is still plenty of room for improvement and matchmaking with more reliable and experienced steam accounts would certainly help. Also as a new or returning player another hint of warning. In the lower Gold Nova and Silver ranks you will get a lot of hot headed angry players that can be pretty toxic or annoying. Sometimes in a 4 player team up you are always at threat of being kicked from the match, even if you are the most productive player while they blast their mic's in a foreign language making no effort to communicate with you, they wait till its a definite win and kick you. Valve really need to incorporate protection for players against that but I guess it would be hard to gauge what protects you and what does not, though I am sure it could be done.

CS:GO is basically the game that makes you keep craving for more and more.
It's a fun FPS game with great matchmaking and balanced guns, with the exception of P90.
Aim is needed for this game, for sure. Once you get the hang of it, using a gun that's hard will be fun and rewarding.

This game is a lot of fun if you decide to play with your friends and have fun while winning than keep blaming your friends. I used to be salty, once. Not anymore!

+Almost everything is a plus
-The uselessness of XP, seriously, why bother adding experience system if people dont get any sense of achievement after leveling up? If you get a skin, most of the time its going to be a really ugly skin, and if you get a case, that's it, either you sell it, or you buy a key to unlock the case.
-Money-hungry devs. I'm not gonna lie, almost everything costs real money here. Yes, it's just cosmetics, but that doesn't justify Valve's money-hungry behavior. Even sprays cost money. Some of them might be cheap, even so, you can run out of sprays, and if you do run out, you'll have to buy it again. It's not permanent.

All the XP things aside, this game is still a 10/10 in my book.

Global Offensive is definitely a Counter-Strike sequel - it looks and feels familiar, with minor tweaks here and there to help balance old issues and surprise longtime players. This is a demanding, skill-based multiplayer game that's as satisfying now as it ever was, but it's for a specific kind of player. If you're not willing to learn to play different than you're used to, look elsewhere. Otherwise, this is a top-tier tactics game that will probably share the long-tailed legacy of its predecessors. It's purely brilliant.

Decided to re-write my review of this game, this time being a much more well-written review.

Well, here we have the latest game in the Counter-Strike franchise. And it's a damn good one.

Graphics: The graphics are very nice, and it shows definativeily in several of the maps, like Aztec.

Gameplay: The gameplay is solid, fun and at times intense. The way the weapons work is one of the reasons i like the game, they're less accurate when you shoot while moving or if you spray bullets all the time. This forces you to shoot in controlled bursts most of the time.

Music: The music is epic, and i honestly didn't expect that in a Valve game.

You can also obtain skins in the game through random drops. They're completely cosmetic, equipping a skin won't make the weapon more powerful. But it makes them look cool.

Overall, CS: GO is worth every single €. Get it if you like FPS's.

A warning though, if you've played a lot of CS: S and CS 1.6, getting used to GO can take a while.

I've determined that Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is from another dimension. It's a game that doesn't need to exist. PC gamers (thousands of them, according to SteamGraph ) are perfectly served by Counter-Strike: Source and CS 1.6 , content with the decade-something of tuning and attention those games have received.

But here's GO: full of doppelganger Desert Eagles and de_dust déjà vu, quantum-leaping from some parallel timeline whose game industry briefly intersected with ours. Playing it is like running into a college crush at the supermarket. You immediately notice differences. Oh, you're married? Your hair looks different. But that experience of reconnecting is pleasant—they're mostly still the person you admired during geology.

In other words, GO's familiarity helps and hurts. Minor deviations from the CS you might've known or loved are easy to identify. The MP5 is now the MP7, but it lacks the same clicky report and underdoggy “this is all I can afford, please don't kill me” personality. The TMP is replaced by the MP9. Ragdoll physics don't persist after death, curiously. You can't attach a suppressor to the M4 for some reason.

I'm not particularly bothered by this stuff; I don't need the MP5 reproduced precisely as it existed in 2004 or 2000 to live a fulfilling life. What does bug me are some small but significant changes to firing feedback. When you shoot someone in GO, they don't wince. There's a sneeze of blood, and audio that conveys that you're hitting them if you're within a certain range. But they don't do this , and I don't understand the decision to omit a flinch animation on character models.

Especially at long range, it takes a little more effort and squinting than it should to tell if I'm hitting someone or not. And counterintuitively, bullet tracers, new in this version of CS, are an unreliable source of feedback. They seem to trail the path of your actual bullet by a few microseconds. With rifles and SMGs, my eyes would wander away from my enemy and crosshairs--what I should be watching--and try to interpret where my bullets were falling based on the slightly-delayed, streaky particle effects. The small upside to tracers is that they mitigate camping a bit.

Counter-Strike Global Offensive ist das Spiel, welches den Ruf hat, skillbasiert zu sein. Diesen Skill kann man in Valve's Matchmaking-System messen. Das Ziel des Spielens ist demnach das Erreichen einer möglichst hohen Skillgruppe. Jedoch wird man auf diesem Weg als neuer Counter-Strike Spieler sicher merken, dass je höher man kommt, man immer mehr Hacker trifft, die einem den Spielspaß nehmen. Seitdem Valve das Prime Matchmaking eingeführt hat, lässt man den neuen Spielern, die mit non-Prime spielen müssen keine Chance sich spielerisch zu entfalten. Nun könnte man argumentieren, dass diese Trennung aus dem Grund sinnvoll sei, dass die erfahrenen Spieler sich nicht mit dem Hacker Problem beschäftigen müssen, was jedoch keine schlüssige Argumentation ist, da es auch sehr wohl auch im Prime MM viele Hacker befinden. Nun können jedoch MM-Alternativen wie ESEA oder FaceIt viel geringere Anzahlen an Hackern vorweisen. Aus diesem Grund muss Valve definitiv an ihrem VAC noch einmal kräftig Hand anlegen. Valve's Dienst Overwatch kann von Cheatern ebenfalls gemieden werden, indem man in 24 Stunden nicht auf seine elf Reports kommt, weil diese anschließend gelöscht werden. An dieser Stelle wäre eine viel bessere Lösung die Reports pro Spiel und nicht pro Zeit zu bestimmen, was es den Hackern deutlich schwerer mache, zu spielen.

Abschließend lässt sich sagen, dass das Prinzip des Spiels hervorragend ist, aber man jedoch noch deutlich an den Ausschlüssen von Hackern arbeiten muss.

[h1] The sequel to one of the most popular competitive games. [/h1]

[*] [b] The game features new modes, and above all competitive matches that I've been playing most of the time. You can play the mod servers of course too on server browser like in 1.6. Unfortunately, there is not a predator mod that I've loved on 1.6! [/b]

[*] [b] The gameplay is, in my opinion, a step forward compared to 1.6 or Source. Weapons require dexterity and skill (e.g. AK-47). The maps are remastered and still enjoyable. [/b]

[*] [b] The game contains microtransactions in the form of skins and sprays which I personally ignore because I like the normal models of weapons. [/b]

[*] [b] Unfortunately you can run into a cheater, griefer or a dirty child, therefore I recommend to play with friends! [/b]

The BEST Counter-Strike game so far! Instead of being a graphical reimprovement, and such, CS:GO is a HUGE reimprovement for an already great franchise, this delivers new things to the table. Such as the Desert Eagle now being one of the MOST innacurate guns in the whole game (Negev doesn't count), rather than being the 2nd most accurate. Everything is improved tremendously, the graphics, the lighting, everything! There ARE some things though that annoy me.

THE CONS
-It feels like there's STILL barely any content. Don't get me wrong there's a lot but it feels like the GUNS themselves could use more. Such as a Remington which increases damage but slows you down, or a minigun that deals MASSIVE damage as a SUPER fast fire rate, but makes you move 1/100 of your movement speed. It could also use more variations to gamemodes instead of the classic 'Bomb' and 'Hostage', such as, one I came up with myself, when the CTs take Terrorists as hostage, known as the Counter-Hostage, and escorting VIPs to special areas (Tactical Intervention, tsk) and more.
-Some maps, such as Lake, were graphical, lighting, etc. remakes of L4D's maps. A fan, whose name I will not mention, realized this and I felt that Valve was just being lazy. It's nitpicking, but it's also kinda true.
-UPDATE YOUR SOUNDS! Seriously! We've been hearing the same walking, gunfire, reloading, etc. noises for almost SIXTEEN YEARS! If you're gonna release a new CS game after 5+ years, update the sounds at least!
-There could be more bombsites instead of A and B. I also wish they did what L4D2 did, changed many routes to give maps a TON of replayability. Again, it's nitpicking, but it's true.

The final verdict for this game, IMO, is an 8.7 out of 10. It's a GREAT game, despite the bugs and exploits (Vertigo, tsk tsk) it's worth the $15. It keeps what makes the Counter-Strike series stand out (no regenerating health, very limited ammo, etc.) and I hope that the next is better. OH YEAH FUN FACTS: 1) Terrorists used the same password for over 10 years. 2) This is even better than CoD gameplay-wise.

Certainly a game you have to stick at for a while to have any sort of fun with!

More often than not I am frustrated by my inability to hit simple targets due to the way recoil works; for people like me it can be a brilliant game one moment and horrible the next.

The player base in match making seems mostly comprised of people who's main aim in life is to tell you how much you suck at video games and generally treat you with contempt and unfriendliness, but if you play with friends and ignore the unpleasant mob, you can find a rewarding game, and even some genuinely friendly people who are there to help you improve or just have fun in bad situations.

Before jumping into competitive, it's probably wise to familiarise yourself with the rules, as friendly fire and dodgy internet connections alike can result in temporary bans.

The graphics are quite nice, some of the voice work is a bit weird to me, but often a source of hilarity.

Death is a great teacher. Failure in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is, as it always has been for this series, the greatest way to learn where you should have gone, what you shouldn't have done, and how you could have done better. Counter-Strike players spend a lot of time learning -- consequently, they are always getting better.

Growth is an important factor in Global Offensive, especially if you're coming into Counter-Strike fresh or after a sabbatical. This is an extremely hardcore, skill-based first-person shooter, and it forces you to think differently than other modern shooters. If you’re a Call of Duty player, you’re going to need to change your play style to succeed here. Counter-Strike also tries developing into something new here as well, despite doing little to push itself beyond what it’s always done best. Global Offensive modifies old maps to keep veterans on their toes, and introduces official new modes that encourage different play styles for the first time in almost 15 years.

For the uninitiated, Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a small-scale, team-based first-person shooter with permanent death. When a counter-terrorist kills a terrorist planting explosives in a classic Defusal match, or a CT escort swallows a sniper round in Hostage Rescue, the victim is dead for good and doesn't respawn until the next round. As such, players on both sides must exercise skill and care. The bomb objective, meanwhile, gives everyone a purpose. Of course matches end when everyone on a team is dead, but a clever and coordinated terrorist team will give the CTs the slip, plant their bomb, and protect the bomb site. Between rounds, everyone spends earned cash on better gear and guns, and the cycle continues.

Pieces of the Counter-Strike formula are dated at this point, but the superb heart and soul of Global Offensive is timeless. Teams are small, guns are lethal, and rounds are short. There's an addictive just-one-more-round quality to it, because there's a constant desire to do better than last time, to earn a satisfying kill, or to win in a new way. Call of Duty and Battlefield vets will wonder why they can't sprint to escape enemy fire or look down the iron sights to improve aim; Counter-Strike players will feel like they walked into their redecorated home. Certain map redesigns will catch hardcore fans off guard, but the changes are for the best -- the underpass choke point in de_dust, for instance, has a new escape route.

Even in the face of genre evolution, Global Offensive doesn’t care to adapt. CSGO is so dedicated to Counter-Strike's aging ideals despite market and trend changes that it brute-forces its way to success. Part of what makes it such an engaging competitive game is that killing in Global Offensive requires a wholly different skill set than other shooters. Everyone is limited to what they have and can see, with little room for character modification or on-the-fly advantages. Running and gunning is a useless play style, even if you've bought a helmet and kevlar that round, to the point that someone standing still is more likely to score the kill. Walking, crouching, or standing are your best bets to reduce the inaccurate spray of machine-gun fire

Consequently, killing in Global Offensive feels good. There's a sickening sensation to dropping someone dead because you know they're not coming back. It's also satisfying knowing you used limited resources to play smarter than your victim. If players aren't watching corners, providing covering fire, or using smoke grenades and flashbangs, they're more likely to take a headshot from a more delicate and patient triggerman. The desire to experience that distinct feeling is a strong motivator to keep playing, even when you're getting steamrolled by an obviously better team.

If you've played Counter-Strike before, Global Offensive probably sounds a whole lot like Counter-Strike. Like Counter-Strike: Source before it, Global Offensive exists simply to modernize the look of the classic competitive shooter, while doing little to disrupt the core form and function. At the same time, it does enough to color outside the lines of tradition to justify your time and effort.

Fire is one of the most interesting new combat variables. Molotov cocktails and incendiary grenades either roast groups of guys or force them in another direction. Flames are a useful distraction or scare tactic, too. They're particularly useful during Demolition matches, which focus the fight at a single bomb site rather than giving terrorists two to pick between. The new and modified maps in this mode aren't as big as classic Counter-Strike arenas – entire sections have been cut off to direct teams toward a central location – but their thoughtful design is as intricate as ever. The Lake map is a standout -- there's a wide open yet densely populated yard around the bomb site, which is inside a sizable lakeside home with plenty of vantage points and hiding spots. To separate Demolition from Defusal, players can't buy between rounds. Instead, it takes a cue from the other new mode, Arms Race, in which each kill unlocks another weapon instantly. The better you do, the more you have to switch up the way you play, and because Demolition is so fast you'll need to be quick on your feet.

I thought CS 1.6 or Quake would never be outdated but CS:GO managed to make it. I'll go straight to the point: this is the best multiplayer shooter game.
A real game for esport and casual competition:
- a great gameplay for huge possibilities for whoever can appreciate fps games.
- an addictive game when you find a team or people to play with.
- graphics are great (cs source players, you're going to feel a change)
- a high required level of skill, strategy and game sense, so a really competitive community (that's not CoD, kids).

And the game is still young and probably going to be still improved.

My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 16, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is the current dominating first person shooter on the market, being one of the best Valve money-makers and Twitch.tv's love child.

The first 500 hours of gameplay with the new meta consists of AWP throwing, fake flashes and cheaters with an occasional smurf. CS:GO is not a game for new-comers as non-prime is like your first extra hot chicken at Nandos, it fucks you up real good going down but coming out it makes you cry like you've never cried before.

The next 1000 hours of CS:GO is you either smurfing 90% of your time because you hit global and you are bored as fuck or you continue to play and become a CS:GO YouTuber and earn shit loads and scam kids out of their pocket money on gambling sites with your fake odds. If you hit Global you have to take a flashy screenshot and post it on your profile to show how egotistical and how much of an asshole you are.

My conclusion of CS:GO is that no-one enjoys it. Fuck this shitty broken ass game that makes you more angry than feminists. This game makes me wanna die.

Hello!
Well, I don't know... This game is still one of my favourites for quite a long time and I think it will stay that way. There would be basically nothing wrong with this game if it didn't have so many cheaters or smurf , but despite that you can still enjoy it if you have prime and at least have 2-3 service medals , because then you are unlikely to get cheated . The graphics of the game are competitive wingman modes are impeccable . I haven't found any major bugs in the game yet except for a couple of hitbox bugs , but maybe I cheated my opponent or I looked in.
The whole point of the game is to enjoy it , but these constant annoyances , why don't you just give up is a bit boring in my opinion , because I don't know why so many people are looking at each other's rank when the point is not to enjoy playing together? I guess I will never find an answer to that , because there are few players who don't care about the other rank , but despite that I still think it is one of the best games ! I recommend it to anyone who is not the rage-preferring type !

Lets face it, the game is a lot of fun and you get to meet quite a bit of people (Some TOXIC)  and some turn out to be really good friends and if you lucky, you might even meet the person of your dreams (WHOOP WHOOP).... With the introduction of the Operation Pass it's made the game a lot more, "I want to play this"..... HOWEVER.... Match Making is just rubbish and lets not even get into their VAC system  cause there are a lot of people using 3rd party scripts (takes a long time for someone to get vac'd who cheats in the game), that might cost you a keyboard, or a mouse... some cases a monitor and a rank or 2 or 3 or 4... So if you want to just be casual and have a bit of fun, sure give it a go... if you want to rank up, be prepared to spend a bit of money cause like I said, playing against people with 3rd party scripts (CSGO community calls them hackers)  might cost you a bit of gear...

This game had really been a blast to play with friends. I'm not good at this game at all but I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes playing online with friends. Theirs so much stuff you can do in this game, you can hide in a toilet, the maps are really well made with secret tunnels and pathways hidden around the map, and the community for this game is incredible. just like the game it's the community as aged like fine wine. People make some pretty creative maps, they got minecraft, tf2, even lego. But I got to tell you the game is not easy in the slightest. If you play call of duty shit this is not the game for you. Their is no scoping with any guns other then snipers and the have some big recoil, and I mean BIG recoil. But ya I recommend this game. If not for you then tell others about it cause this is one of those shooters where it really brought people together to do and make some incredible things. Hope you have some fun and what ever you do, don't shoot the chickens. You monster.

I bought this game for the chickens, and was not disappointed. After exploring the countless lands the chickens have traveled far and wide, I realized their population was growing too large. The chickens had started to inhabit such horrid locations across the world, such as nuclear plants, and offices without cafeterias. I knew what had to be done. I bought a flip knife off of the steam market, and called PETA. I listened to In the Arms of an Angel in my Microsoft Professional Deluxe Gaming Chair 360 for about twelve hours with no response, so, I decided to take matters into my own hands. I loaded up de_nuke and started to put the chickens out of their misery. I cried harder that night than I have ever before.

The next morning, with tears in my eyes, I loaded up Counter-Strike: Global Chicken, and I saw a new item waiting in my inventory. My Flip Knife had turned into a Flip Knife Slaughter. At that moment, I realized what a horrible thing I had done.
With my hand shaking, I navigated my mouse, and uninstalled Counter-Strike: Global Chicken.

I regret everything I have done. I am writing this review to warn you about the chickens, and to let you know I have made a full recovery, and that I have started my new journey in Goat Simulator. Thank you, and farewell.

Community is filled with mentally stable, rational, humble players dedicated to having fun while improving, not merely ranking up and flaming enemies and/or teammates.
VAC is literally flawless on this game, never before have I encountered someone who I think twice about being absolutely 100% legitimate.
CS:GO developers have truly pruned this game into the best FPS of all time with their consistent efforts into listening to the community, bringing regular updates, game balancing patches and exciting new operations into Counter-Strike: Global Offensive.

This is by me top 5 FPS shooter games that ever existed. CSGO have all aspects of game I was searching for. Teamwork, skill, economy, strategy and fun. All of those come with your mentality and how you deal with people. Why? CSGO have really toxic community in lower ranks. You need to deal with different types of people all the time. Thats why you have to practice communication skills too.

Prime status is your main goal when you start the game. Dont get discouraged by cheaters in non prime matches. They will get what they deserve and you stay cool and never be like them. After you get prime you will encounter less cheater, yes they still exist because they hide cheat well.

Advancing trough ranks is easy when you have your friends with you... soo play as much as you can with friends- game will be more fun and less toxic if you have full team(5 people).

remember to practice everyday essential skills on workshop maps like Aimbotz, Recoil master, Reflex maps YPRAC maps for smokes and other nades.

Practice, assemble your team of good friends. Train together and you will reach MG1 really fast.

Hope this review helps. :D

Things I gave CS:GO
  1. Money
  2. Time

Things CS:GO gave me
  1. Many great friendships
  2. Broken keyboards/mouses/mics/headphones
  3. Dumb Russians/Turkish people/ Hungarians that can't speak english or can't understand a simple command
  4. Kids that use cheats to feel great one time in their life and then to forget about the game forever
  5. A lot of wasted nights that I could have spent in bed but I always told myself "Just one more game will give me that sweet rank" "I don't care that I'm carrying my team that rank will be juicy"

Do I recommend this game? No. If you are a new player that doesn't know that much about FPS games your experience as a non-prime player in silver will be horrible you will either get carried by smurfs which will make the game boring for you or you will get your matches ruined by cheaters. The one thing I recommend if you are planning on playing this game is: buy an account that is in gold nova and gather a good team of 5 [1 reserve] and try to have fun this game might be all about being competitive but trust me a few jokes make the matches pass like they are 10 minute rounds!

Edit: If you get to mg2-mge you are better off getting cheats yourself and start having fun because from this point this game turns into Counter Smurf:Global Offensive / Cheater Strike:Global hackers

A game where two sides fight each other to be the victor. It has many game modes but the most played one is competitive mode. In this mode, Terrorists' goal is to plant a bomb at the marked site or to prevent counter-terrorists from saving hostages. It is  counter-terrorists' job to keep the peace. Counter-terrorists could win by defusing the bomb, saving the hostages, or eliminating the terrorists. 

CS:GO is the game that I played most. The game itself is very competitive, but majority of the players are not. Most of them are toxic and don't care about others. There are smurfers (Players who are actually high rankers but playing with low rank accounts), hackers and bullies. I would not recommend it for kids who are underage as these type of players could break their mentality and lead them to have bad morale. On the other hand, if you are a careless person, this game could be enjoyable. 

Their server is another issue that should be solved. Playing online with friends is more fun that playing offline. We, Indonesian, always have problem with connection. However our friends from other countries in Asia seems that they don't have problem with connection. It's either Indonesia's internet or CSGO's server is the problem. I hope Valve do something about it.

Still, I recommend this game because of the action and visual. The satisfaction you got everytime you succeeded to pull a difficult move will hype the whole team including yourself. 

Overall it's a good game with many upsides and downsides. My advice before playing this game is try to get the prime status so that you won't meet any hackers or smurfers. I hope this review could help you decide to play or buy this game.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The game it self i very good. If you are bored, you can still play community servers, insteed of keep grinding to be the best on matchmaking servers. CS:GO or Counter Strike : Global Offensive isnt expensive, and can be afford by anyone with a computer. Dosent tage that much fps, if you have a bad computer. If you tho still feel you have bad fps, then you can lower so many settings, which makes CS:GO a really nice game. Every person can learn and play this. I've seen everyone transform from bad to very good, but practice and time is the key. Hook up with some your friends, and the experince will be better.

NOTICE! There are many scammers online on CS:GO servers. Never press links from someone you dont know IRL (In Real Life) or someone you dont trust. Many thoudsans gets scammed every year, and i dont want you to be that person.
Also get the Steam Autenicator, then you are even more protected.
I hope this helped.
