I have decided after 3 years and well over 4500 hours (on 4 accounts) of on and off toxicity of this horrendous yet wonderful game, I should finally share my thoughts and opinions on what I find good and bad. So, grab a drink, preferably a vodka or a Eastern European varient if you really want to fit in with the others, and lets get started!

I bought CS:GO in the Summer of 2015, after I had just graduated High school and my friend told me I should get it to play with him. Enthusiastic me thought it was a great idea, after all I had a computer that could run it at a solid 80 FPS on high settings, and I always had a consistent 90+ ping to every server, what could possibly go wrong? Spoiler Alert: I didn't play it actually, I quit the game 3 hours in with the exact words "Boring and predictable". Man, I couldn't have been more wrong...

During the rise of Leafy's latest and greatest videos in 2016, I found myself curious of the surfing game he was playing, venturing onwards once more into the great unknown abyss to a massive expanse of fanboys and try hards. I couldn't complain though, right? Hell, I was just surfing for the first 400 hours, what did I know about this game besides strafing and looking around in a smooth mannered way?! Turns out, a lot. From Leafy, I jumped ship to none other than WarOwl, the greatest thing to ever help noobs in counter strike since the invention of aim lock. Now that's an adventure I'm not going to type up because you want to know why you should download this now free game, Hell it's free, but is the time investment worth it? Well...

Along the way of my adventures in CS:GO, I found these free modes that weren't competitive called Arms Race and Demolition, and from there I met the one person who brought me around to staying in this game for the next 3 years. That's all this game is for people, Friends and competition. If you're looking to come into this by yourself and turn out to be the next big pro, I'll go ahead and stop you now, you'll find more success asking out the girl in school who's a lesbian. (This is towards the majority of guys who play the game, go get em' girl) 

All in all, yes this game is wildly successful for a reason, and absolutely worth getting. Have I hated a majority of it, yes. Will I continue to hate everything about this game, probably. What makes this game worth playing then, it's not such an easy answer. In short, Friends, Friendly competitiveness, and all in all, the small 2% of nice people you'll meet.  I do recommend!

Big shout out to Mehbie, Nova, Jakob, Ozvu, Luckey, DJ, Colin, NoCashNoFriends, Jared, Shorty, Richie, Pepper, Didkimo, Mo, Lilli, and many many more. These guys made/make the game worth playing, every bit of it.

(People to watch out for. Polish, Turkish, Spain, Turkey, Russia, and Americans. ^.^)

Counter-Strike is the definitive twitch shooter.

You're teamed up with 5 people for about an hour and you have to prove better than the other team. While some teammates are annoying or obnoxiously toxic; the fun of CS:GO is being able to overcome it through your skill. CS:GO is full of diverse weapons with a great system of skins that help diversify your inventory. It's a great way to make friends on steam and I hope you buy the prime version, because the free version is full of hackers that Valve is too lazy to ban at this point.

My name is Sebastian, nickname Vaken.I'm 18 and most of my life I've played a game called Counter-Strike.I got my first PC at the age of 6, when I also found out about this game.I was little, and didn't know there is a Competitive part of it aswell, mostly playing Counter-Strike 1.6 on Furien, Zombies, Jail Break, Surf and B-hop.

I was 11 when I first played a 5v5 game, I joined a new thing called...TeamSpeak?I was so nervous I remember cause most of the people there were way ahead of my age, but slowly growing with them.I was so good and so motivated to learn more that actually everyone was calling me a cheater, and ending up getting banned and unbanned from most of the communities that were active at that time.And no, I was not cheating.

I started playing Counter-Strike: Global Offensive back in 2017 for the first time, while I had a really bad PC, playing mostly under 60 fps.Got my first good PC back in 2019, and started playing faceit for the first time.I was obviousely way ahead of everyone, because of such an experience I had during CS 1.6.

I always wished to become a PRO Player, I still think I have the abilities and let's hope one day my dream will become true!

Thank you Valve, for such memories we've done togheter! ❤

 If you think matchmaking is boring/broken you can always play on faceit or esea servers in a more competitive surroundings witch i recommend doing.

Intro
CS:GO is a fun multiplayer game, the VAC system is superb at banning cheaters and the ranking system places you into the correct rank to play with players at your skill level. This makes it fair for everyone in the game! 

The Great:
+ Operations are released with new missions and maps
+ Various medals for collection
+ Huge range of skins to purchase
+ Multiple game modes to play 
+ Reporting cheaters does work and gets them banned 

The Bad:
- There are some toxic players
- Some areas of the game are infested with hackers
- No 128 tick servers 
- Trust factor placement is questionable 
- Hard to master

Sound: 10/10
Graphics: 10/10
Gameplay: 10/10
Content/Replayability: 10/10
Overall: 10/10

Conclusion
CS:GO is the best game and forever will be!

CS:GO is a unique competitive online team-based FPS. Every player at the start of a match starts equally, there isn't any upgrades or perks that make your character better. Its a hardcore skill-based game that takes weapon recoil to another level, and in Counter Strike, you can't just turn your brain off and run around not knowing what you're doing, it requires skill. The game requires teamwork with your teammates to win, it's a team-based game in which every team is trying to achieve their objective. I think that CS:GO is one of the best FPS's out there. Definately one of my favourites.

Since starting TF2 in early 2013, CSGO has become my all-time favorite multiplayer game and the best competitive experience of any game I've played. I have a blast playing Wingman and competitive matches with all my friends and seeing how we've grown in skill and playstyle. As well as learning new strategies and the little things that can make a difference. This game has a steep but fair learning curve and rewards patience and tactics like no other. It's rigorous but enjoyable as long as you have the right state of mind and perspective.

In conclusion, it's a great multiplayer co-operative team based game that executes to its strengths very well. After all, Valve has pretty much pioneered the industry from over 20 years of Counter Strike. So you know they know what's up. Just stick with it and give it time and soon you'll be a bona-fide, first person shooter, BOSS.

Overall

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is overall a pretty good game, but naturally it is not flawless. I've been playing this game for about a year now and I run into quite a lot of problems, the most prominent one being cheaters and griefers. This game has a massive cheating problem, but VACnet is doing a decent job. It learns about new cheats fairly quickly, and doesnt the job pretty well. Now that the game has gone free to play, VACnet needs to be better and more efficient. I imagine the cheating problem will be much worse, and Valve has probably taken this into consideration. Then, they made a Battle Royale type gamode recently and they have done a really good job on it. But, now that the gamemode has been implemented, AMD users are experiencing regular crashes and sometimes cannot start the game. The servers are 64tick, meaning that the hitreg will be slightly inaccurate. I personally think that valve should upgrade their official servers to 128tick, so the gameplay and fairness will be improved.

This is a pretty good game in itself but the toxic community makes matchmaking a very bad experience in lower ranks. I mostly enjoy this game because of great community servers, the graphics, which is ok, but can be enhanced a bit with a few commands. I also like it because in offline mode you can change up the looks of weapons, your hands, character models and even enhance the graphics with some cool effects. Even in online mode you can change the panorama ui background, the font, you can use a text color mode which adds colors to different texts and change up the texts and the best thing is you can chnge the viewmodel, crosshair and gui with only commands inside csgo or in an autexec file. In conclusion I like csgo because it's a fun game, you can customize it as you want it to be and it doesn't take up a lot of space on your pc.

[b]I decided to rewrite this review because this game deserves it![/b]

No wonder CS is 20+ years old. This game is so addictive. I was never really into gaming but this game changed my opinion. This is one of the most accurate FPS games ever made with 128 tick servers. This game requires passion, dedication, hardwork, skill & a lot of practice because every pixel counts when you trigger you gun. 

When you will play on low tier like Silver & Gold Nova you may lose many games because of your teammates. They may do basic mistakes like Run & Gun, Team Flash etc. But never rage on them. Always remember we used to do the same basic mistakes when we were beginners. I know this game involves lot of emotion but keep your calm & make sure to teach the beginners. Our community is already toxic, lets not make it more.

You win or you learn, you never lose.

[b]CS will never die.[/b]

[b][u][h1]⇜⇜⇜⇜⇜⇜⇜⇜⇜⇜⇜⇜Lunny's Review⇝⇝⇝⇝⇝⇝⇝⇝⇝⇝⇝⇝[/h1][/u][/b]
[b]This game is kind of a mixed bag for me. In and of itself it's kind of mediocre and the game developers don't seem to pay that much attention to it anymore. However, the game's biggest strenght, the simple mechanics, is what really carries it for me. The game is really easy to get into but has a really high skill curve due to it not featuring any sort of aim assist or bloom and overall being very punishing against inexperienced players, especially against higher elo players.[/b]

I probably won't have a popular opinion here but it is how I feel none the less.
I played CS a lot when it was first released as a mod for Half-life. I put hundreds of hours into both pub matches and matches with my friends in private servers. I stopped playing it at about the time that it was about to make the move to a retail product

Counter-strike as a franchise is something of a time capsule. It is a example of a late 90's shooter frozen in time that never really changes and that is probably what makes it both novel for the average gamer and important for the competitive scene that has formed around it (and taken control of it in a lot of ways).Because a e-sports style competitive scene has formed around Counter-strike, it puts Valve in a difficult position because they can't really change anything without facing harsh resistance from the veteran players. Even minor visual changes are met with extreme criticism because they may upset the carefully cultivated meta.

It was not always like this. When I was playing, the idea of e-sports level competitive play was only just starting to manifest and thus it was more rare to find the ultra-competitive players who get wrapped up in memorizing spread patterns, researching dominant strategies and reading up on the established meta. A lot of players back then were just there because it was fun to play and had a huge playerbase (thus meaning that servers were always reasonably available).Playing Counter-strike back then was not the commitment that it can be now. The overall behavior of the playerbase was different. You may have gotten the usual smack talk during a match but you did not have people telling you to do things exactly this certain way in order for the whole thing to play out like a E-sports match either (at least not in any great number).

[i]The game's matchmaking system is very simple and is pretty much comparable to any other game's in the industry. If you win enough, you rank up, you loose enough, you derank. This ranking system is what has held this game alive for all these years. It's REALLY difficult for people to reach the top and as someone who has only reached LE (Legendary Eagle), the 4th highest rank in the game, I can safely say that the game demands dedication, and much of it. This might scare newcomers but it's what in my opinion makes the game so appealing, especially after so many years of playing.[/i]

[u]Overall I think the game is a very skilldemanding game with a huge skill curve which is very rewarding whilst you've mastered it. With decent graphics and great mechanics it still holds up today in this fps-crowded landscape. And also, it's free! <3[/u]

CS:GO - a game that will make you win-greedy.

CS:GO used to be a great game, always had fun playing mostly comptetitively.
It's a game for people that are looking to become really good into a game and like slow-paced gameplay.
Don't expect that being good in Overwatch will automatically make you good in CS:GO, since the gameplay is very different.
CS:GO, also standing for Counter Strike: Global Offensive has a long story of rise and (somewhat) fall. You will have a hard time getting out of the no-rank zone, where you must play with people that are first-timers, like you, or people that have 1000+ hours just warming-up.
Do not expect this to be a friendly game for people to relax. Competitive gameplay is just the kind of fun people have. And yes, you heard me right. People that play this game have more than a 1000 hours on it. I know people that have more than 3000 (some of which make a living off of this game). And this game does have lootboxes but worry not, they are just cosmetics that do not affect the gameplay in any way.
Some people also make a living off of trading. Which is also very advanced.
----------------------------------------------
How the game works and what you're expected to do:
If you're a newbie (noob), you might stay away from the competitive matches and learn how to:
~Strafe,
~Peek,
~Flank,
~Positions,
~Grenade shortcuts,
~Maps,
~Team build,
~Recoil patterns of various weapons,
~Crosshair placement,
~Team placement and 
~How different weapons behave and when to use which.

This might seem like a lot, but most of them are things that take about 10 minutes to learn, but of course, you have to practice them. And don't worry, you can play this game as a hobby.
Most of these stuff can be learned through YouTube videos, chats, coaches/friends, the community on Reddit, Steam and verious different websites or etc.

When you think that you are ready for competitive gaming, you will realise that most of the people you're playing with are kids or people that don't talk your language and have completely no knowledge of the game.
Most of the time you shouldn't worry, because you can also find good teams on special website to build teams.

After winning 10 matches, give yourself a pat on the back. You have reached your first rank! 
Silver 1.
Now, one thing that you should worry about in competitive matches are smurfs or hackers. This is why you should almost never play solo if you want to win.
Smurfs are people that have a higher rank, silver 5 for example, but play on a second account or intentionally lose to rank down so they can play vs. lower-skilled players.

Also, after getting through, let's say Silver 2, and you're now Silver 3, it's time for you to start warming up!
You can warm-up by playing stuff like Deatchmaches, or casual (the place where you started) or download maps from the workshop page. The workshop page is a place full of nicely put togheter maps for different purposes.
There are maps for learning how to Strafe, throw grenades or anything from above!
And of course maps for warming-up!

Community servers:

CS:GO is not jsut a standard shooting game, you can also do things such as surf, bhop or play various different mods, that can be found on the community servers.

I really hope that this review helped you decide if you want to play this game or not.

~ Lepto.

Counter-Strike makes you work to enjoy the content, and you'll have to put many hours of play into it before enjoying the feeling of conquering it.

Weapons are a huge part of the series too, with CS:GO not an exception. Each round provides a cash sum based on your previous performance, and with this you can purchase armour, projectiles and weapons. Firearms range from standard assault rifles to shotguns and sniper rifles, and you'll want to experiment with each one to see which works best.

What makes Counter-Strike such a popular series - and what will no doubt make CS:GO the next big PC shooter - is the thrill of the ego chase. As you die, often continuously, the frustration is outweighed by an aspiration to do better. In a game where success is pinned on attention to detail, death often triggers an internal failure analysis that the player will mull over while waiting for a new session to load. It becomes a spiral of egging yourself on to do better - and if you become a good player, the game becomes a stage for you to parade your skills.

Global Offensive builds on the CS series by going through a significant checklist presented by its community and marking off as many points as possible. Gun game as its own separate mode? Check. Competitive capabilities built in? Check! Map balancing here and there? Check, check, check.

As a result, there are numerous upgrades that will adjust gameplay while also making accessibility far better. The wide range of grenades, for example, will likely make play more tactical - laying down incendiary grenades will thwart rushes, while decoys, which fake gunfire and fool radar points, are brilliant tools for messing with the minds of established players.

The actual core shooting will be a huge talking point for many months to come. It has been tinkered slightly and gives weapons a noticeably floaty feel, which doesn't sit well to begin with. We eventually found ourselves enamoured by it, and the impact of hits add a real tactile distinction to play.

It's what doesn't work, however, that is most notable. Regular mode has no new maps added to it, while all the new guns seem somewhat cosmetic. Global Offensive has also removed some of its middling weapons such as the MP5, essentially pushing even more players to stick with the AK and the M4. Sometimes it gives the impression that there is in fact less valuable content than in previous CS releases.

If one assumed this was Counter-Strike Source with a visual mod installed, there would often be little to shake that impression.

There's also now a split between casual and competitive servers - however, many players aren't yet aware of the differences, mainly because the distinction isn't made obvious enough. It becomes even more confusing if you join a community server with all hosts of mods installed on it, which have perhaps taken casual mode, turned friendly fire on and essentially made it as close to Source as possible.

At times, arranging games in Competitive Mode feels like a chore. Joining a five-on-five war is simple enough, but attempt to lobby up with a group of friends and join a game, and you'll often hit a snag. Myself and a few others tried to find a competitive game with no luck, simply being told that no servers were currently available.

When you finally do join, it works fine, but the wait and work required to find a game seems like a drawback. We eventually gave up and resorted to using IRC to find matches, as we would with Source.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is not the key evolution point that we were hoping for, and the response from the community often reflects this view. On many occasions, other players used phrases such as "same old" to us.

This is elementally Counter-Strike Source with some fine-tuning under the bonnet, and Valve appears to have acknowledged this with the reasonable RRP attached to it.

And yet the core DNA of the game has not lost its appeal. This is still a glorious experience that sets a benchmark for all multiplayer shooters. Valve's objective with Global Offensive was to draw together the active communities of both the Source and trusty 1.6 edition. It clearly has a good chance.

Death is a great teacher. Failure in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is, as it always has been for this series, the greatest way to learn where you should have gone, what you shouldn't have done, and how you could have done better. Counter-Strike players spend a lot of time learning -- consequently, they are always getting better.

Growth is an important factor in Global Offensive, especially if you're coming into Counter-Strike fresh or after a sabbatical. This is an extremely hardcore, skill-based first-person shooter, and it forces you to think differently than other modern shooters. If you’re a Call of Duty player, you’re going to need to change your play style to succeed here. Counter-Strike also tries developing into something new here as well, despite doing little to push itself beyond what it’s always done best. Global Offensive modifies old maps to keep veterans on their toes, and introduces official new modes that encourage different play styles for the first time in almost 15 years.

For the uninitiated, Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a small-scale, team-based first-person shooter with permanent death. When a counter-terrorist kills a terrorist planting explosives in a classic Defusal match, or a CT escort swallows a sniper round in Hostage Rescue, the victim is dead for good and doesn't respawn until the next round. As such, players on both sides must exercise skill and care. The bomb objective, meanwhile, gives everyone a purpose. Of course matches end when everyone on a team is dead, but a clever and coordinated terrorist team will give the CTs the slip, plant their bomb, and protect the bomb site. Between rounds, everyone spends earned cash on better gear and guns, and the cycle continues.

Pieces of the Counter-Strike formula are dated at this point, but the superb heart and soul of Global Offensive is timeless. Teams are small, guns are lethal, and rounds are short. There's an addictive just-one-more-round quality to it, because there's a constant desire to do better than last time, to earn a satisfying kill, or to win in a new way. Call of Duty and Battlefield vets will wonder why they can't sprint to escape enemy fire or look down the iron sights to improve aim; Counter-Strike players will feel like they walked into their redecorated home. Certain map redesigns will catch hardcore fans off guard, but the changes are for the best -- the underpass choke point in de_dust, for instance, has a new escape route.

Even in the face of genre evolution, Global Offensive doesn’t care to adapt. CSGO is so dedicated to Counter-Strike's aging ideals despite market and trend changes that it brute-forces its way to success. Part of what makes it such an engaging competitive game is that killing in Global Offensive requires a wholly different skill set than other shooters. Everyone is limited to what they have and can see, with little room for character modification or on-the-fly advantages. Running and gunning is a useless play style, even if you've bought a helmet and kevlar that round, to the point that someone standing still is more likely to score the kill. Walking, crouching, or standing are your best bets to reduce the inaccurate spray of machine-gun fire.

Consequently, killing in Global Offensive feels good. There's a sickening sensation to dropping someone dead because you know they're not coming back. It's also satisfying knowing you used limited resources to play smarter than your victim. If players aren't watching corners, providing covering fire, or using smoke grenades and flashbangs, they're more likely to take a headshot from a more delicate and patient triggerman. The desire to experience that distinct feeling is a strong motivator to keep playing, even when you're getting steamrolled by an obviously better team.

If you've played Counter-Strike before, Global Offensive probably sounds a whole lot like Counter-Strike. Like Counter-Strike: Source before it, Global Offensive exists simply to modernize the look of the classic competitive shooter, while doing little to disrupt the core form and function. At the same time, it does enough to color outside the lines of tradition to justify your time and effort.

Fire is one of the most interesting new combat variables. Molotov cocktails and incendiary grenades either roast groups of guys or force them in another direction. Flames are a useful distraction or scare tactic, too. They're particularly useful during Demolition matches, which focus the fight at a single bomb site rather than giving terrorists two to pick between. The new and modified maps in this mode aren't as big as classic Counter-Strike arenas – entire sections have been cut off to direct teams toward a central location – but their thoughtful design is as intricate as ever. The Lake map is a standout -- there's a wide open yet densely populated yard around the bomb site, which is inside a sizable lakeside home with plenty of vantage points and hiding spots. To separate Demolition from Defusal, players can't buy between rounds. Instead, it takes a cue from the other new mode, Arms Race, in which each kill unlocks another weapon instantly. The better you do, the more you have to switch up the way you play, and because Demolition is so fast you'll need to be quick on your feet.

Unlike other game types, Arms Race allows for respawns. It's the most chaotic and care-free mode in Global Offensive, with players throwing caution to the wind for the sake of climbing the kill ladder as quickly as possible. It's a shame there are only two maps in Arms Race -- a problem that will more likely persist on consoles than PC.

If you have the option, playing the PC version is unquestionably the best way to experience Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. Mods, mouse and keyboard, and the usual PC-only options are better than the ports. Plus, Valve is much better about long-term PC support -- it abandoned Team Fortress 2 on consoles, and Portal 2's level editor was PC exclusive. If you prefer to play on consoles, Global Offensive is the same great game

Hi, counter strike global offensive is a skill based game.
I played it now for nearly 2000 hours, so i am a very confident player.
The matchmaking system from valve is a nice idea but the preasure of a rank can make you very mad sometimes.
I played in nearly in every rank of matchmaking, and you often play against cheaters in the higher ranks.
Especially non-prime matchmaking is unplayable in higher ranks.
Overall you should just play and try to get better, ignore the cheaters and just report them.

There are a few more competetive modes beside matchmaking from valve, for example faceit.
Its based on the same bomb scenario , but it gets played on private servers from faceit.
That means less cheaters because they have a better anti-cheat system, There are also skill based ranks from 1-10.
Faceit is a good variety to matchmaking!

A little tip from my side, play with your friends in a 5 man lobby, or you will get russians with 3000 hours who can't even pronounce their names right...

A game with a simple objective but deep and complex mechanics, counter strike is a game for beginners and professionals, young and old and serious and casual players. If you've ever heard of "video games" in the modern time, chances are you've heard of counter strike. Be it the classic 1.6 that started it all or the upgrade source. Counter strike has been the most popular game in the last decade and has been dominating the market. However does counter strike global offensive (commonly known as csgo) hold up to all the hype and does it perform well to continue the legacy? The answer is yes. Cs go is a master piece of a game. And it certainly deserves to be one of the best, if not the best game of all times. I've been a player of 1.6 and played it for a long time, however due to a recommendation by a friend (shoutout to @ganjaboss) I decided to switch to go, and man I wasn't disappointed one bit. It certainly redeems it price and adds much more to the experience. The fluidity and gameplay experience was on point. After playing 1.6 it took a while to adjust to the mechanics but the out come of all the hard work and effort you put into the game is skill which no one can take away from you. 

Skills are a big part of the competitive scene of cs go, but to all the newbies out there, you don't have to play competitive right away. You can just play the casual mode of the game to get used to the mechanics. 

The mechanics of the game is the factor that seals the deal for me. The fluidity in the game play and the rewarding nature of the game is appreciated.

But the most important factor that has made the game so popular is the community involvement. Now while you may encounter toxic players every now and then, it is inevitable in every multiplayer game to encounter such players. However worry not those toxic players can't outweigh the good experiences you'll have during the game and the friends you'll make along the way.

So if you're thinking of buying the game however you fear that the game might be "dead", here's a statistic; csgo recently crossed dota 2 in player base.

Don't hesitate, buy the game, you'll love it.

Hello there, are you looking for some advice on the global sensation of "Counter-Strike Global Offensive"?? Then look no further! I shall tell you exactly what to expect before downloading this shrine of a game created by Valve!

Firstly, I would just like to point out that I have been playing this game for many years along with achieving "The Global Elite" across many accounts (thanks shroud!). Across all of my accounts I have roughly around 12,456 hrs (and that isn't counting time in the menu!!). I hope this assures you that I know exactly what I'm talking about. :P

Counter-Strike has always had a place in my heart. When I would come home from school after getting bullied for watching too much anime, I would always log on to my pc and load up CSGO. It was amazing. The game helped me forget about the hard times I go through at my place of education, and my friendly English-speaking team would always reassure me that things were going to get better! If it wasn't for CSGO, I probably would have committed suicide back in 2003! I am forever grateful for this game as it helped me through the hard patch in my life, and it helped me continue to become stronger in the real world!
However, not too long ago, Valve decided to make this game Free-to-play, and my lord was that a terr-- such a good idea!!!
Hackers no longer exist in lobbies. TK-ing and griefing in general just does not happen anymore, IT IS AMAZING. I would like to meet the member of staff at Valve that suggested to make the game free-to-play and personally thank them and take them for a pint down at the local brewery.

To conclude, Counter-Strike Global Offensive is probably the best competitive rank-based game out on Steam! I will continue to play this game 26 hours a day and watch it grow into something even bigger. That's all from me today guys! Happy Hacking!!

Counter Strike: Global Offensive - Or as i like to call it - Counter Strike: Russian Aggressive
Just when you think you couldn't find a game more triggering than Call of duty, fifa or League of Nerdlands, CS:GOHome allows you to vent your frustration both to your Eastern European friends as well as the 4Q Stack of Russians in your team who do not speak a word of english except from profanities. They seem to all be reproducing with your mother,sister and brother, even if you don't have a brother. Next up we have the ranking system, why play against players of your own skill level when you can play against players who have 10X more experience than you? CS:GO allows you to do this with the HIDDEN smurf system. Great players create new accounts and play against players much below their skill level in order to teach these new players good lessons about smashing their keyboards off of their walls and breaking their vocal cords in rage. On to the next topic, Cheating. Counter Strike: Hacker Offensive includes an in-built VAC system or as i like to call it, Valve Allow Cheating. Why play against players with your own two hands when you can have a computer program instantly land head shots for you? Or the ability to see through walls to hunt down your enemies like a doctor carrying out an X-Ray scan on a patient.

I spend more time on playing Cs:Go then every other Pc game in the last time.
This game sure has its up and downsites but if you can get into it it will be one of the best games you will ever play.

Pros:
-More skillbased then any other shooter out there
-Most of the weapons are pretty good balanced (there are a few which should be rebalanced in my opinion)
-You really need to invest some time into the game to get better like practice aim, smokes, movement, recoilpatterns and all that stuff because its so much different to other shooters (for others this might be a con but I like it that there is always more you can learn about the game)
-Various different gamemodes (most of them are really fun to play)
-A great competetive matchmaking system

Cons:
-This game has a problem with hackers, although I face them by far not as often as others say in their review
- As I said, some guns need a rebalance (Why can you kill with one headshot with a 300$ Pistol but not with a 3100$ Rifle?)
- The 64Tick matchmaking servers 
-Not really a problem with the game itself but once you got a Cs:Go inventory worth 200$ or more you will get friend request spammed by scammers (Valve should really get rid of them)
-When you are playing non-prime matchmaking and/or in a lower skillgroup you will face plenty of smurfs who will totally f**** you in the a** without lube.



I can understand that some players on lower skillgroups rage about this game, calling it broken and full of hackers.
But once I got out of the silver leagues (I'm DMG now) it all got better and better.
The community isnt as toxic in my rank as it is in the lower ones and I even enjoy playing solo-q. 
From time to time you will meet toxic players who wont stop insulting everyone and everything while playing worse then a brain dead monkey.
But I also met great people in Solo Q and I still play hours of Cs with those randoms from Solo Q, who became friends by now.

If you are looking for a game which you can buy and immediately start stomping enemys just because you are naturally good at shooters then you wont have any fun with Cs:Go.
You will die... a lot.
And you may come to a point where you think to yourself "I really want to get better in this game!".

Ive been playing this game for a little over a year now, and I can say this is one of my favorite strategic games, even getting higher than League of Legends. 

The only thing thats a huge downfall is the immense amount of people using cheats to get ahead of the game. It really does take the competative and thought-provoking aspect of the game and tear it from you.

But other than that, its a fantastic round based game. Once you get to a level where you can get Prime Matchmaking, things do go alot smoother, and the people you play against are 95% legitimate players. Your losing games are lost to players of proper skill instead of a random smurf or cheater. And thats something I can respect.

My biggest reccomendation is that Valve invests in an anti-cheat system that recognizes files from various cheating programs and work around trying to erradicate the pandemic. Another reccomendation would be making Prime Matchmaking Mandatory. A linked phone number to a CSGO account really does cut down on cheaters and smurfs by a cluster buttload. 

Otherwise, a wonderful, tactical, and strategic game mixed with a need to train your reaction time and precision. A perfect game for the focused gamer.

Who doesn’t love the traditional breakfast of Indonesian fried rice, served with all the salty, sweet, spiced flavours of Asia  and topped with a sunny-side-up egg.

This recipe borrows the local secrets to give you the nasi goreng recipe to make Chronicles this popular Sonderverkauf dish from your own kitchen.

​Nasi Goreng Recipe (Indonesian Fried Rice) ​
Serves 4

INGREDIENTS
Fried rice:

    5-6 cups cooked & cooled from long grain rice
    2 tbsp. honey
    2 tbsp. tamari or Soy Sauce
    1 tbsp. sweet chilli sauce
    1 tbsp. butter
    1 brown onion, thinly sliced
    3 garlic cloves, finely chopped
    1 tsp. shrimp paste
    1 tsp. sambal
    1 carrot, peeled, finely chopped
    1 Gallery small chicken breast fillet, chopped (or pork)
    8-10 prawns, peeled and deviened
    3 shallots,  thinly sliced
    1/4 small Chinese dicccabbage, finely shredded
    4 eggs, fried sunny-side-up
    sliced cucumber
    thinly slices red chillies


METHOD

1. Combine honey, soy sauce and sweet chilli sauce in a bowl & set aside.
2. Heat butter in wok over high heat. Add brown onion, sambal, garlic, shrimp paste and carrot. Stir-fry for around 1 minute or until aromatic and onion is translucent
3. Add chicken to wok. Stir-fry for 2 to 3 minutes or until sealed. Add prawns and stir-fry for another to 2 minutes.
4. To the  wok, add rice, soy mixture, shallots and small chinese cabbage. Stir-fry for 5 minutes or until rice is heated through.
5. Spoon nasi goreng onto serving plates, top with prawny fried egg and cucumber, chilli.

If you're looking for a game review you've come to the wrong place. But if youre looking for a fantastic ravioli recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients
- To Make the Dough
375 grams (3 cups) plain flour
1/2 teaspoon salt
2 eggs
1/4 cup (50 ml / 3½ tablespoons) olive oil
1/2 cup (120 ml / 8 tablespoons) water
Extra flour for dusting 


- To Make Cheese Filling
15 ounces (425 grams) container Ricotta cheese
5 ounces (142 g/about 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons) "3 Cheese Italian Blend" (Parmesan, Romano & Asiago)
Note: grate these cheeses yourself and create your own custom blend.
1/2 cup cheddar cheese
2 eggs, lightly beaten
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon pepper


- Extras
Your favorite sauce for the ravioli (i.e. marinara/ marijuana)
Parmesan cheese
Basil
Fried vegetables
Shrimp
Fish slices
Chicken pieces 
Make the Ravioli filling.

- In a small mixing bowl, add the ricotta and mash with a fork.
- Add in the 3-cheese blend, Cheddar cheese, eggs, salt, and pepper.
- Mix all ingredients thoroughly until you have a smooth, paste-like consistency.
- Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and place it in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes. 

Make the Ravioli dough.

- Crack eggs into a large mixing bowl and beat them with a fork. Add water, oil, and salt. Mix.
- Add 1 cup flour to the bowl. Use a fork to mix the flour with the eggs, water, oil, and salt. Repeat with the rest of the flour. Mix until a smooth dough is formed.
- Clear and clean off a large work surface and dust it with flour. This is where you are going to roll out your dough.
- Take the dough out of the mixing bowl, shape it into a ball, and place it on your work surface. Knead for at least 10 minutes or until it becomes elastic.
- Dust a rolling pin with flour to prevent the dough from sticking. Roll out the dough until it is about 1/8 inch (1/3 cm) thick, or about the thickness of 2 stacked quarters.
- With a cookie cutter or upside-down water glass, cut out circles in the dough (will make about 15-20 dough circles).
- Ball up the unused dough and either roll it out and make a couple more raviolis, or wrap it and put in the freezer for another time. Dough can keep for weeks when frozen. Just make sure to wrap well so that it doesn’t suffer from freezer burn or absorb freezer odor. 

Fill the Ravioli shells.

- Take the ravioli filling out of the refrigerator and place a tablespoon of it in middle of a dough.
- Fill a small bowl with water, dip your fingers in, and moisten around the outer edge of the dough circle.
- Fold the dough in half over the filling, making a half-moon shape. Be sure all the filling stays inside. Pinch the edges together and then seal the edges of the ravioli with a fork. Make sure to press firmly and go all the way around. This will add a “homemade” touch as well.
- Repeat this process for all your dough circles.
- Dust the finished ravioli with flour to keep them from sticking together. 

Form the Shells and Fill Using a Ravioli maker.

- Roll the dough into two sheets
- Place one sheet on the ravioli maker, and form the filling cups.
- Fill with the ravioli mixture.
- Lay the second sheet of dough on top, and roll it out. This will seal in the filling.
- Remove and separate the finished raviolis.

Cook the Ravioli.

- Fill a large pot with water and bring to a boil.
- Place the ravioli in boiling water for 5-6 minutes, or until they float. You can also test for doneness by nibbling on the edges to test.
- If you don't want to make all the ravioli at one time, you can freeze the rest 
- Take ravioli out of boiling water with large slotted spoon and place on warmed plates

Serve it up.
Top with your favorite sauce, grate some fresh cheese over it, and enjoy!

At the time of writing this review, I have:
• 1063 Hours
• 499 Wins
• Ranked to 'Glowball' about 10 minutes ago
• A decent understanding of the game

Lets start by saying this game is not for anyone with a short temper, nor anyone who is not willing to work as a team. The best advice I can give it to "Communicate in Comp, be deaf in Deathmatch". So let's tackle the CS:GO Stereotype... Russians. They are no problem, just like any other player you should never antagonize, annoy or shoot in the general direction of (Unless they do the same to you) I mean just mute them and let them do their thang gurl.

Cheaters... "Nice Hacks, enjoy VAC and Overwatch ban" I hear this too much... Like every game (Silver 1 > MG2) but truth be told they are just a better player. The amount of cheaters have decreased massively and if you are unlucky to play with one... Hang around or spin bot. You will lose but when they get banned you effectively win that game. And for Christ sake, if there is one on your team REPORT & KICK THEM!

What comes next...? Well I have no idea. I always expected the unexpected but this game keeps giving. New boosts, hidey spots, wall bangs and those bloody sound updates. WHO asked for those Volvo? Let alone 3 of them in 1 year. All this aside I am now Global and have only just scratched the surface.
This game deserves my "Thumbs Up" and I take great pleasure in saying...

Death is a great teacher. Failure in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is, as it always has been for this series, the greatest way to learn where you should have gone, what you shouldn't have done, and how you could have done better. Counter-Strike players spend a lot of time learning -- consequently, they are always getting better.

Growth is an important factor in Global Offensive, especially if you're coming into Counter-Strike fresh or after a sabbatical. This is an extremely hardcore, skill-based first-person shooter, and it forces you to think differently than other modern shooters. If you’re a Call of Duty player, you’re going to need to change your play style to succeed here. Counter-Strike also tries developing into something new here as well, despite doing little to push itself beyond what it’s always done best. Global Offensive modifies old maps to keep veterans on their toes, and introduces official new modes that encourage different play styles for the first time in almost 15 years.

For the uninitiated, Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a small-scale, team-based first-person shooter with permanent death. When a counter-terrorist kills a terrorist planting explosives in a classic Defusal match, or a CT escort swallows a sniper round in Hostage Rescue, the victim is dead for good and doesn't respawn until the next round. As such, players on both sides must exercise skill and care. The bomb objective, meanwhile, gives everyone a purpose. Of course matches end when everyone on a team is dead, but a clever and coordinated terrorist team will give the CTs the slip, plant their bomb, and protect the bomb site. Between rounds, everyone spends earned cash on better gear and guns, and the cycle continues.

Pieces of the Counter-Strike formula are dated at this point, but the superb heart and soul of Global Offensive is timeless. Teams are small, guns are lethal, and rounds are short. There's an addictive just-one-more-round quality to it, because there's a constant desire to do better than last time, to earn a satisfying kill, or to win in a new way. Call of Duty and Battlefield vets will wonder why they can't sprint to escape enemy fire or look down the iron sights to improve aim; Counter-Strike players will feel like they walked into their redecorated home. Certain map redesigns will catch hardcore fans off guard, but the changes are for the best -- the underpass choke point in de_dust, for instance, has a new escape route.

Even in the face of genre evolution, Global Offensive doesn’t care to adapt. CSGO is so dedicated to Counter-Strike's aging ideals despite market and trend changes that it brute-forces its way to success. Part of what makes it such an engaging competitive game is that killing in Global Offensive requires a wholly different skill set than other shooters. Everyone is limited to what they have and can see, with little room for character modification or on-the-fly advantages. Running and gunning is a useless play style, even if you've bought a helmet and kevlar that round, to the point that someone standing still is more likely to score the kill. Walking, crouching, or standing are your best bets to reduce the inaccurate spray of machine-gun fire.

Consequently, killing in Global Offensive feels good. There's a sickening sensation to dropping someone dead because you know they're not coming back. It's also satisfying knowing you used limited resources to play smarter than your victim. If players aren't watching corners, providing covering fire, or using smoke grenades and flashbangs, they're more likely to take a headshot from a more delicate and patient triggerman. The desire to experience that distinct feeling is a strong motivator to keep playing, even when you're getting steamrolled by an obviously better team.

If you've played Counter-Strike before, Global Offensive probably sounds a whole lot like Counter-Strike. Like Counter-Strike: Source before it, Global Offensive exists simply to modernize the look of the classic competitive shooter, while doing little to disrupt the core form and function. At the same time, it does enough to color outside the lines of tradition to justify your time and effort.

Fire is one of the most interesting new combat variables. Molotov cocktails and incendiary grenades either roast groups of guys or force them in another direction. Flames are a useful distraction or scare tactic, too. They're particularly useful during Demolition matches, which focus the fight at a single bomb site rather than giving terrorists two to pick between. The new and modified maps in this mode aren't as big as classic Counter-Strike arenas – entire sections have been cut off to direct teams toward a central location – but their thoughtful design is as intricate as ever. The Lake map is a standout -- there's a wide open yet densely populated yard around the bomb site, which is inside a sizable lakeside home with plenty of vantage points and hiding spots. To separate Demolition from Defusal, players can't buy between rounds. Instead, it takes a cue from the other new mode, Arms Race, in which each kill unlocks another weapon instantly. The better you do, the more you have to switch up the way you play, and because Demolition is so fast you'll need to be quick on your feet.

Unlike other game types, Arms Race allows for respawns. It's the most chaotic and care-free mode in Global Offensive, with players throwing caution to the wind for the sake of climbing the kill ladder as quickly as possible. It's a shame there are only two maps in Arms Race -- a problem that will more likely persist on consoles than PC.

If you have the option, playing the PC version is unquestionably the best way to experience Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. Mods, mouse and keyboard, and the usual PC-only options are better than the ports. Plus, Valve is much better about long-term PC support -- it abandoned Team Fortress 2 on consoles, and Portal 2's level editor was PC exclusive. If you prefer to play on consoles, Global Offensive is the same great game

If you are new to the series, here’s what you can expect. CS is a slow-paced game -- funny thing is that it was pretty fast in the days of Rainbow Six - where two teams try to eliminate each other while attempting a secondary objective (rescue hostages or plant a bomb). The two defining features of the game are the permanent death that forces players to spectate until the next round begins, and the ability to purchase weapons and equipment at the start of each round with money earned from kills and victories. You can find these features in Call of Duty’s Search and Destroy mode as well as Shadowrun (2007), but outside a couple mods for Quake and Unreal Tournament no one has attempted to replicate the full package.

It might not be quite as good as the classic GoldSrc Counter-Strike outings, but CSGO (known in development as Counter-Strike 1.5) is the first proper entry Valve has done since acquiring the franchise, and it does a very good job of bringing Counter-Strike back to the fold while making sure it still is Counter-Strike. 

GO sticks to the classic maps, mechanics, and weapons, while adding a few new of each, but without diluting or harming what makes its gameplay great. At launch, it was a mess (and it still has a few aspects which need touching up), but today it's a really great game with a growing, vibrant competitive scene and a pretty lively cosmetic economy. And with ongoing content updates and service from Valve, it's only going to get better!

CS:GO is a game made for competitive gameplay, but that doesn't mean it has to be serious all the time.
At one time or another almost every player has picked up a zeus and just ran around the map trying to taze someone and had the time of their life while doing it.
It's a fun game to play with friends for sure, unless you wish to take it to the competitive level instead of the casual aspect of the game.

It's a pretty straight forward game, you walk around shooting the bad guys, pretty simple right? That's how the game's played by the more casual player. Competitive players take the game to the next level. You have a somewhat realistic spray control (ignoring the fact that you have to aim at the floor sometimes), a complex teamwork involving grenades, timing and strategies.

CS:GO presents immersive graphics, realistic and well detailed while still having the ability to have a nice amount of FPS. It presents a really nice attention to detail, being able to notice every action from the character's movement to the weapons firing and even to the trajectory of the grenades being thrown, people even write things on walls with the bullet holes.

One of the most important aspects of this game is sound and Valve didn't miss a thing in it.
You can tell just by the sound where your enemy is and on what material he's running and with the recent updates to the weapons' sounds, it just got even more realistic.
The existence of Music Kits help the game music wise, adding a completely custom Main Menu music and in game sound effects change that can be chosen by any player according to their taste.

Playing this the competitive way like I did, I don't consider it a big time consuming game since a single competitive match takes about 1 hour to finish if it's a "close" one, while a match that you're completely mowing your opponents can take about 15 minutes. It's not an addicting game, you will still be able to have a life while playing this game.

I recommend this game 100% It's a whole new experience learning new things about this game, playing with different people from all around the world and just having fun. Many players have said that it's easier playing other FPS games if you first learned playing CS:GO an then moved to other games instead of the other way around.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie 

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Growth is an important factor in Global Offensive, especially if you're coming into Counter-Strike fresh or after a sabbatical. This is an extremely hardcore, skill-based first-person shooter, and it forces you to think differently than other modern shooters. If you’re a Call of Duty player, you’re going to need to change your play style to succeed here. Counter-Strike also tries developing into something new here as well, despite doing little to push itself beyond what it’s always done best. Global Offensive modifies old maps to keep veterans on their toes, and introduces official new modes that encourage different play styles for the first time in almost 15 years.

Cory in the House is a television show, which aired on the Disney Channel from January 12, 2007 to September 12, 2008 and was a spin-off from the Disney show That's So Raven. The show focuses on Cory Baxter, who moves from San Francisco, California to Washington, D.C. with his father, after Victor Baxter gets a new job in the White House as the official head chef. The series marks a Disney Channel first, as it is the channel's first spin-off. This is also the only Disney Channel spin-off series to be broadcast in standard definition for the entire length of the show. Reruns of the series have not been produced on Disney Channel, or on Disney XD; however they continue to air on the Family channel in Canada. Raven-Symoné guest-starred, reprising her role as Raven Baxter in one episode. In 2014 Disney Channel started airing a weekly block called Disney Replay on Wednesdays nights, during which episodes of Cory in the House air alongside That's So Raven and Kim Possible, among others.

10/10 Best game ever :D

Well after 600+ hours of playing this game it should be easier to write a better Review than 9/10 most Gametime in fewest time.

Now to the actual review:

Counter Strike Global Offensive or in the community the so called "CSGO" is a first person tactical shooter. 

I first played it in the Winter of 2016 and didn't really likeit.
 -Why?
Because I wasn't familiar with the gunplay and all the tactics. It was a difficult start in which someone had to force me to play. As I reached level 3 the fun began to rise. This was because I played against players on my skill level. So it was fair, not like the usual "Casual" Mode in which i first was forced to play.

After 200 hours I somehow got the gunplay right but still not perfect and now I'm still learning the grenade tactics and also still the gunplay. It isn't anymore like: "I want to shoot down an apple from a head and hit the foot of my teammate standing 5 meters away" but more like: "I want to shoot down the apple and hit the body".

Also there are cheaters but in my time playing the game I didn't encounter that many. The bigger problem are the smurfs here which got more seldom (At least for me).

If you look at my friends reviews you will see that they wrot a review about the game in which they don't recommend it. Mostly this is because they were toxic sometime because of not getting anything done. There also are these moments for me but I mostly blame myself and not the others which helps me with my aggression at those times and you should too. 

So for conclusion:

CSGO is a game which is hard to like at the start but easy to love after learning it. It is hard to learn and hard to master. But still fun when you finally can play in competetive. Cheaters and Smurfs are there but not as much as you would think.

The game has it's problems (e.g.: 32 tick Servers, microtransactions and bad cheat detection) but still it is fun to play.



I want end this review with a request:

Please don't be toxic.
You will only destroy the fun for yourself and your teammates.
If you are toxic take a break and do something else. (e.g.: playing Barbie Games that should help)

Thank you.

This is one of those games that you see and think 'How are people enjoying this?'.
I was exactly the same a couple years back; before I spent some time playing it. Originally, I was doing what a typical FPS player would do, running and gunning, hoping for the best. Only after around ~100 hours did I start getting into watching streamers and professional matches. This is when I became inspired to become better. 

As of now, I've played just over 2000 hours, making this (probably) my most played game. Ever.
It's given me so many memories of joy, relief and heartbreak. But one of the best things it has given is friends. And I don't mean this in the sense that I was completely alone before playing this but that I've gotten to know them so well and have met up with some of them now to go to a CSGO Major. I get frustrated at the game sometimes, blaming others but it is still easily one of my all time favourite games. I may find a new game. One that I enjoy more than this, but I will never forget the memories and friendships that CSGO has given me.

Thank you, Valve.

Ever wanted to play CSGO? well I'm about to tell you the very basics of CSGO.
In Counter Strike: Global Offensive there are 2 sides

Counter Terrorists and Terrorists, the Counter Terrorists have to win the round by either
killing all the Terrorists, running down the clock, or defusing the bomb.
The Terrorists have to win the round by either killing all the Counter Terrorists or planting
and exploding the bomb. There is also another Hostage gamemode that no one plays because it is
shit.
both of these teams have different items and
weapons, and unlike other games, you have to buy them. I won't get into the value
of everything ever in this video I'll just tell you the basics

For the Terrorist your options are the Galil AR, a 2000 dollar rifle that has
good tapping power, alright close range sprays but if you take this any longer
range than half a block then you're going to have some problems.
The 2700 AK-47, this is your bread and butter in CS, the AK is to CS what
the acoustic guitar is to music, if you want to get into the business, this is what
you should at least know the basics of. It's got amazing tapping power mid to long range
but the spray is wild, but you can learn to control it, I'll tell you about that later.
Basically the Ak-47 is a heavy duty assault rifle that'll cut through everything.

And for the Counter Terrorists we have the FAMAS, M4A1-S and the M4A4

The FAMAS cost 2250 and has 2 firing modes, burst and automatic, with burst you get incredibly
high accuracy on the first shot, but you need to wait half a second between each 3 bullet
burst. Automatic is best if you're trying to run somewhere, being able to fire more than
3 bullets will save your life, you can right click to change between these modes, and if you
pick up the FAMAS from a dead enemy, you can check the bottom right, just below your ammo
if it's in burst or automatic.

The M4A1-S is a highly accurate rifle with a silencer that removes the tracers your bullets
usually give, and it has a very easy to control spray, but is neudered by the fact that it only
has 20 bullets per clip and only 2 extra clips, amounting to a grand total of 60 bullets.

The M4A4 is as accurate sa the M4A1-S, and does as much damage but doesn't have the silencer,
so why do I prefer the M4A4? I spray a lot, because I've learned the spray patterns, so the 30
bullet clip and the way more reserve ammo allows me to worry a lot less about running out of ammo
It took 10 kills in warmup for me to run out of ammo on the M4A4 for the first time EVER.

Both the M4A4 and the M4A1-S both cost 3100 dollars and do less damage than the 2700 dollar
Ak-47. Why is this?

Because the Counter Terrorist side is an easier side to play on, you are playing defensively
and you don't have to be very clever to hold angles and tell where the enemy is, but at least
you don't have to buy helmets because the Ak-47 chews through it anyway, the only time you should
buy helmet is when you know the enemy has SMGs or Pistols, which can 1 hit kill you without a
helmet, so look out for that.

In addition to all of this, Counter Terrorist's Molotovs have a stupid and hard to spell name
And they cost 600 dollars, to contrast the Terrorist's Molotovs do more damage, and cost 400
dollars.

Once the bomb is planted, the remaining Terrorists have to hold the bombsite long enough for it
to explode, and the Counter Terrorists, depending on what the team's money is, what weapons they
are currently holding, and how many there are left after the bombplant have to do one of a few things

1. Retake the bombsite

This is if the people on your team who was holding the bombsite the bomb was planted at (normally
2 players) managed to take down 2 of the Terrorists on their way into the bombsite before they died.
And if you are holding a bombsite, your job is to stop the bombplant from going down with your life
never let the bomb go down, if you are holding a bombsite and they are planting, try your very best
to rush in there and take it. Now the job of the remaining players, who at this point are 3v3, is to
get back into the bombsite, which is a lot like the Terrorists taking the bombsite initially, and
defuse that bomb. Which is why you have to buy a defuse kit, because it normally takes 10 seconds
to defuse a bomb, doesn't sound like much, but a lot can happen in 10 seconds, a defuse kit cuts
that time in half, and if you manage to kill all of the Terrorists and defuse the bomb, your team
wins the round and the person who got 1 kill and defused gets the "Most Valuable Player" star.

2. Go for exit frags

This is if the people who were holding the bombsite went down without getting anything, and your
economy (your team's average money) is enough for a full-buy next round regardless, you set your
remaining 2-3 players on the exits to the bombsites and try and kill the enemy

3. Save

This is if the people who were holding the bombsite went down without getting anything, and your
economy is dogs bollocks. You hide in some distant and obscure part of the map hoping the Terrorists
don't hunt you down and kill you and steal your weapon.

Now you know all there is to know about the basics of the basics, now I'll tell you the VERY basics
of economy

If you win a round and then lose the next, force the next round, if you lose that too, eco, and then
on the next round, you can full buy. This is called the WarOwl buying guide.

Here's the reasoning behind it, and there's a bit of math coming now so buckle up.

If you lose 1 in a row you get 1400 dollars, now let's assume you lost in a buy round and you were
left with around 200-800 dollars after everyone had finished buying, this will leave you with around
1600 to 2200 the following round, this is not enough for a buy, or is it? Of course not, you force
buy this round so you can get 1900 next round, or win the round which gives you 3250, and considering
you just won a round and then lost, their economy isn't exactly fantastic.

If you lose the force buy, you've lost 2 in a row and you have 1900, if you full eco at this time
you will have 4300 for next round because the lose 3 in a row bonus is 2400, and if you lose again,
it's 2900, and then it maxes out at 3400. In addition if you're Terrorist and you plant the bomb
and lose, the planter gets an additional 300 bucks, as well as his team and himself gets 800 dollars
at the end of the round. But if you save as a terrorist you will get 0 extra money for the next round.

Now that's all you really need to know about CSGO that you probably didn't already know.

Where do I begin...?

After 2,000+ hours in this game, I have been in countless situations including: smurfs, hackers, toxic players, extreme try-hard players, trolls, and non-skilled players. So, here we go.



If you are a person who can ignore the community and its toxicity:

You will absolutely love this game! I don't have any reason to hate towards this game. The graphics for CS:GO are great for 'bad' computers and computers with insane capabilities. 
Learning the game is the hard, fun part. Every time you login, you may learn how to throw a helpful smoke grenade, or a new position for planting the bomb. 
The best part...clutching. The heart-racing moment when you are the last one alive against two or more enemies. Once you pull off an insane clutch, you learn more about your own, improving skill every single time.



If you can't ignore the community:

You might have a hard time with this game. 

You will encounter 'smurfs' (higher ranked people playing on a lower ranked account) that will tear your game into shreds. 
Hackers (this one is pretty obvious), the people who spin at insane speeds popping heads off where ever you go. This includes the people who can see through walls. 
Try-Hard players, the people who yell at you for not being good enough and "causing your team to lose". They may even get upset with the opponent team because they are doing well.
Toxic players (yep, the ones who get upset at the drop of a hat), if you speak, type, play, or breath incorrectly, you arise the Hulk out of them.
Then you have the trolls/derankers (the people trying to get their accounts to a lower rank by purposely losing the game), team killing, mic spamming, and 'knife only' players. *If you have a troll in your game, it is usually (90% of the time) game over.
Last, you have the non-skilled players. These guys decided to play on a higher ranked account even though they may be two-five ranks lower and play horribly. You usually don't encounter these people, but they are out there. (e.g. a gold nova master ranked player playing on a supreme master first class ranked account).



CONCLUSION:

This game is very enjoyable and can lead you meeting many new friends. However, there are people who want to ruin the game for you and your fellow teammates. The community is probably up on the scale next to League of Legends, but that is a story for another day. You will rarely get one "good game". 

One more thing...
If you are new to Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, you may have people telling you "don't play competitive until you are good enough". After going through the war-zone of casual and death match, you will be experienced enough to start playing to earn your rank. Play "OFFLINE WITH BOTS" until you are comfortable with playing real competitive games. 
Who knows, you may be part in the next generation of global elites. I mean, we all started somewhere.

Overall : 10/10
The best fps multiplayer experience available today.

Optimization : 10/10
Very good optimization, 298 fps on 1440p-low on a gtx 980 (overclocked).

Learning curve:
Basic principles can be learned in 15 minutes.
After 1700 hours i still haven't mastered this game.

Community : 3/10
The community can be toxic sometimes. I recommend to queue with friends.

Map design : 9/10
Maps are designed very well. New maps are added sometimes to keep the gameplay fresh.

Ranking system: 8/10
You are awarded a rank based upon personel skill level, not hours played.
Problem here is that some players with loads of hours create an alternate "smurf" acount to destroy noobs.
This somewhat destroys the ranking system.

Rewards from playing the game are skins for the weapons, not weapons itself.
This means that everyone has the same weapons and thus the same chance of winning.

Graphics : 6/10
Simplistic graphics. This is done on purpose, you can spot your enemy's faster this way.
Most players play at low graphic settings to get the most fps.

First and foremost, as this is a review, I should tell you the bottom line:

Do I recommend CS:GO? Absolutely.

That said, know what you are getting into. Counter Strike: Global Offensive is a highly competitive game filled with some of the biggest assholes you'll ever meet, some of the most braindead people you'll ever meet, and maybe two people who are actually decent human beings per week, but almost never in the same lobby.

It's best to bring your repetoire of Call of Duty-loving friends and have them sit through the torture of learning spray patterns and getting destroyed by smurfs with you, rather than braving the harsh world of the internet alone. Together, so long as you don't become too consumed in your competitive rankings, most every match will be an enjoyable experience filled with accidentally shooting one friend in the face, while the other bounces a flashbang off your big toe, and the other one spins in spawn to eat some sunflower seeds or grab his hotpockets as your random shouts at you in russian/spanish or complains about his ping.

Personal experience is a bitch.

Also be prepared to be subject to Valve's changing whims on how the game should be played. One week we're just fine, polishing our skills and getting ready for tournaments, and the next we get the "Winter Update!" in which the only good thing comes in the form of chickens wearing sweaters while you deal with the cons of a severely overpowered revolver a-la Clint Eastwood being added into the game, the rifle spray patters suddenly becoming luck of the draw, and pistols, known for good moving accuracy, suddenly being twice as inaccurate. 

On the bright side, they fixed the revolver in 2-3 days, and it only took them about a week to notice that everybody was preparing their StatTrak™ Pitchfork|Slaughter(s) to march down to Valve HQ and have a word with the design team.

As far as pros go:

- Feel rewarded for tactical play 10x more than Call of Duty or similar shooters
- Actually have to strategize and learn to use some skill by learning spray patterns that reward you for being good instead of lucky... most of the time
- Scum it up with a P90 or an Auto and watch the world burn as the people whose very existence you hate get their panties in a bunch
- Pretty Pretty skins for the low cost of an arm and a leg (and your right kidney if you're into StatTrak™)
- Feel rewarded for climbing a ranked ladder in a world where smurfs and hackers run rampant
- Uh..... 
- There's gotta be something.....
- I swear....
- OH RIGHT!
- Listen to "Run" every time the bomb is about to go off by buying a music kit. That's worth the game right there.

After what i consider to be a decent amount of hours spent on this game, i can conclude that there are many different mixed emotions that come with it. 

Happy moments include: Getting an ace, Ranking up, Seeing people call you a hacker because you're THAT good, getting skins.

Sad/Angry moments include: When you get destroyed 16-0, When your teammate AFKs, When the enemy has a hacker(This happens more often than it should), When your teammates mic spam.

Also, Be sure to play this game in moderation as playing it for too long at a time can make it very boring.

Overall, i rate this game an 8/10

I am a terrorist with a simple lifelong dream

To plant a C4 bomb with my 5-strong team

So I got in a queue and waited my turn

Till it was time for my match to confirm

So as the game loaded in I shook with anticipation

Until shrieks of 'cyka' destroyed my feeling of elation

For to my dismay I'd been matched with a clan

Of russian patriots who were stalin's biggest fan

So as the warmup ended they declared 'RASH B'

Their microphones obnoxious and loud as can be

But as they stood in spawn with the timer counting down

On the clan leader's face there began to form a frown

He glared into my eyes with his crosshair on my head

And asked me if I'm russian, for if I'm not I should be dead

But as I replied 'da' I knew I was in a trap

As him and all his mates started spouting russian crap

And I didn't understand a word so I just stood there and waited

Knowing when the round started I was going to be baited

When I found myself alone in tunnels I knew I'd been tricked

But as they rushed out long their leader got picked

So they all crouched in pit with their A rush dream shattered

Not to mention their comrade, whose brains had been splattered

Then along came an enemy with aimhacks and walls

And the russians screamed 'CYKA, THIS GAME SUCKS BALLS'

So they abandoned the match and I was left all alone

With a team of dumb bots who were sadly quite prone

To rush CT spawn with a bizon SMG

And I thought to myself; That's enough CS for me.

This game is amazing. Its the best fps out there. You guys have to understand that the game is extremely hard. You wont get your first kill in the first 5 min. i got mine in the first 30 min >-<.

EDIT 5 YEARS LATER:

This game is ok. It's still one of the best fps games out there. Incredibly fun game at lan parties! You and your friends will create moments that you will remember forever. On the other side, this game will bring you down. It's toxicity gets to even the strongest men out there; If you think you can take it, go ahead. But be warned. They will take you. Anyway, the game has another issue: The "bell curve." This game's ranking system is supposedly based off of a bell curve distribution, putting most players at around the gold nova rank. This is blatantly untrue: I have 30+ friends who play CSGO and not a single one of them is a gold nova. We all lie in the silver ranks. In addition, it is extremely hard to climb out of the silver ranks due to cheaters and smurfs. This is nothing new. You have to put in serious dedication to climb out. If you do, in fact, climb out of silver, You will be left feeling accomplished: but not for long, as the grind will return for you.

In conclusion, this game is a BLAST with buddies!! The problem is the ranking system, which is not accurate in determining your actual skill level. Don't let your competitive skill rank bring you down; You know your better than that and prove yourself worthy. Go be a killer in retake; Dominate in surf servers; Excel in bhop. 

Oh yea, did i forget to mention? Shooting people is have the game in this fps. Community servers are the BEST, if not THE BEST. True men will embrace the opportunity to learn surf and bhop, and will take themselves to new levels in gameplay. This is for me one of the funnest factors of CSGO. 

In conclusion (for real this time) this game is worth the 10$. Oh wait...

After putting in the effort, the game will reward you for your hard efforts, not only in rank gaining, but in skill too. This game saved my life.

I am 42.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

CS:GO started off as a great game, but its starting to go downhill sadly.

The amount of time and money I've put into this game is very sad hence the state the game is in now.  Hackers are at an all time high, the hitreg, hitboxes, and community itself is trash (sometimes I disagree, but most of the time it is).  Valve was heading in the right direction updating the game after it was released.  The only thing saving CS:GO is the skins and the fact it is still being considered an MLG tournament game.  Weapon skins were nice, but new sounds, the R8 (pre-nerf), glove skins, and map revamps (Inferno) were not needed at all.  I still love CSGO, but I'm saddened to say it is nothing like it was when it came out 5 years ago.  And with all this being said, I still do recommend it because you can still find some decency left in this gem.
